original: śrīmadvidyācakravartiviracitā sañjīvanyākhyā vyākhyā viśvaṃ prakāśayati yā jātiguṇādyātmakaiḥ nijaiḥ prasaraiḥ /
analyzed: śrīmat vidyācakravarti viracitā sañjīvanī ākhyā vyākhyā viśvam prakāśayati yā jāti guṇa ādi ātmakaiḥ nijaiḥ prasaraiḥ
translated: The commentary called Sanjivani, composed by the illustrious Vidyachakravarti, illuminates the universe with its own rays consisting of class, quality, etc.

analyzed: saṃskāra guṇa samṛddhā vāṇī mām avatu sarala sandarbhī
translated: May that speech, rich with the qualities of refinement, and having a simple presentation, protect me.

analyzed: rucaka ācārya upajñe sā iyam alaṅkāra sarvasve
translated: This is the commentary on the Alaṅkārasarvasva composed by Acharya Rucika.

analyzed: sañjīvanī iti ṭīkā śrī vidyācakravartinā kriyate
translated: The commentary Sanjivani is being written by the illustrious Vidyachakravarti.

analyzed: udāharaṇa śeṣaḥ tra dhvanau granthakṛtā kṛtaḥ
translated: The author has not given all the examples in this work on Dhvani.

original: tadīyanyāyasampanaiḥ svapadyaiḥ pūrayāmi tam //🔽dhvanidarśanānuraktāḥ sūkṣmekṣikayā nirīkṣya ṭīkāṃ me /
analyzed: tadīya nyāya sampanaiḥ sva padyaiḥ pūrayāmi tam  dhvani darśana anuraktāḥ sūkṣma īkṣikayā nirīkṣya ṭīkām me
translated: I shall fill that gap with my own verses, which are in conformity with his reasoning.🔽Let the poets, even if they are sentient, examine my commentary with a subtle eye, being devoted to the doctrine of Dhvani.

analyzed: kavayaḥ sa cetanāḥ api vitanuta sāhitya sāmrājyam
translated: Let them spread the empire of poetry.

original: kiṃ vistareṇa bahunā ṭīkāṃ sañjīvanīmimāṃ kaścit /
analyzed: kim vistareṇa bahunā ṭīkām sañjīvanīm imām kaścid
translated: What is the use of much talk? If someone hates this commentary Sanjivani,

analyzed: yadi abhyasūyati jaḍaḥ svam eva pāṇḍityam abhyasūyati saḥ
translated: that dull-witted one is only hating his own scholarship.

original: tatra tāvadadhikṛteṣṭadevatānamaskāra puraskāreṇa prakaraṇapratipādyamarthaṃ pratijānīte namaskṛtya paramiti /
analyzed: tatra tāvat adhikṛta iṣṭadevatā namaskāra puraskāreṇa prakaraṇa pratipādyam artham pratijānīte namaskṛtya param iti
translated: There, first, with the salutation to the chosen deity, he announces the subject to be presented in the treatise, by saying Having saluted the Supreme... etc.

original: sarvaiva khalviyaṃ vāk parā paśyantī madhyamā vaikharīti caturbhiḥ padaiḥ parimīyate /
analyzed: sarvā eva khalu iyam vāc parā paśyantī madhyamā vaikharī iti caturbhiḥ padaiḥ parimīyate
translated: Indeed, this entire speech is measured by four terms: the supreme, the seeing, the middle, and the manifest.

analyzed: yat śutiḥ catvāri vāc parimitā padāni iti ādikā
translated: As the scripture says: Speech is limited by four terms. And so on.

analyzed: tatra parā nāma nirupadhikam rūpam
translated: Among them, the supreme is the form without superimposition.

analyzed: paśyantī ādīni trīṇi punar aupādhikāni sthūla tvāt vigraha sthānīyāni
translated: The three, the seeing and so on, are again superimposed, and because of their grossness, they are fit to be embodied.

analyzed: yathā ca āgamaḥ
translated: And as the scripture says:

analyzed: jyotiḥ eva antar parā vāc anapāyinī
translated: The supreme speech within is the light of one's own nature, which never fails.

analyzed: yasyām dṛṣṭa svarūpāyām nivartate
translated: When its form is seen, the authority of the three [other forms of speech] ceases.

analyzed: avibhāgena varṇānām
translated: Without distinction of letters, all-pervading, with the sequence withdrawn,

analyzed: prāṇa āśrayā tu paśyantī mayūra aṇḍa rasa upamā
translated: The seeing [speech] is based on the vital breath, likened to the essence of a peacock's egg.

analyzed: madhyamā buddhi upādānā kṛta varṇa parigrahā
translated: The middle [speech] is based on the intellect, and takes up the formed letters.

original: antaḥsañjalpa rūpā sā na śrotramupasarpati //🔽tālvoṣṭha vyāpṛtti vyaṅgyā parabodhaprakāśinī /
analyzed: antar sañjalpa rūpā sā na śrotram upasarpati  vyaṅgyā para bodha prakāśinī
translated: It is in the form of internal thought, and does not approach the ear.🔽Expressed by the movement of the palate and lips, revealing the supreme understanding,
The manifest [speech] is considered external, easily available to humans.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

analyzed: tatra paśyantī adya para vāc traya apekṣayā jyeṣṭha tvāt ā adya parā
translated: Among them, the supreme is the first because it is the oldest in relation to the three forms of supreme speech beginning with the seeing.

analyzed: dvitīyā viśva abhimukhībhāvāt paśyantī
translated: The second is the paśyantī, facing the universe.

original: tṛtīyā nābhyantarī na ca bāhyeti kṛtvā madhyamā /
analyzed: tṛtīyā na abhyantarī na ca bāhyā iti kṛtvā madhyamā
translated: The third is the madhyamā, not internal nor external.

analyzed: turīyā tu para avabodha artham pravṛttā iti vaikharī
translated: The fourth is the vaikharī, engaged for the purpose of supreme knowledge.

analyzed: yat vā kham sukham duḥkham ca
translated: Or, the universe is the collection of pleasure and pain.

original: tadviśiṣya rāti dadātīti vikharo dehendriyasaṅghātaḥ tatra bhavā vaikharīti jñeyam /
analyzed: tat viśiṣya rāti dadāti iti vikharaḥ deha indriya saṅghātaḥ tatra bhavā vaikharī iti jñeyam
translated: That which grants it is the vaikhara, the aggregate of body and senses. It should be known as existing there.

analyzed: tat eva abhisandhāya uktam vācam trividha vigrahām iti
translated: With that in mind, it is said: the speech with three forms.

analyzed: caturvidhām api
translated: It is also of four kinds.

analyzed: kīdṛśīm devīm
translated: What kind of goddess?

original: parādibhiścaturbhiḥ padaiḥ krīḍantīṃ nāmapūrvakatvāt sarvasyaiva rūpasya jagadetadvijigīṣamāṇāṃ🔽samastavyavahārātmikāṃ svarūpāvabodhakṣamatayā dyutimayīmanyastutaustotavyatāyāṃ
analyzed: para ādibhiḥ caturbhiḥ padaiḥ krīḍantīm nāma pūrvaka tvāt sarvasya eva rūpasya jagat etat vijigīṣamāṇām  samasta vyavahāra ātmikām sva rūpa avabodha kṣama tayā dyuti mayīm anya stutau stotavya tāyām
translated: Playing with the four terms beginning with para, desiring to conquer this world with all its forms,🔽having the nature of all transactions, full of splendor by the ability to understand one's own nature, being able to praise and be praised in the praise of others,

analyzed: ca prabhavantīm avimarśa andha tamasa dhvaṃsanāt kānti mayīm apratihata prasara tvāt gati ātmikām ca iti arthaḥ
translated: full of beauty by destroying the darkness of non-reflection, full of motion by unobstructed movement - this is the meaning.

analyzed: tām imām namaskṛtya
translated: Having bowed to this one,

original: namaskāro hi nāma pṛthagahaṅkāraparityāgena namaskartavyamahimodghāṭanaṃ sāmarasyamiti yāvat /
analyzed: namaskāraḥ hi nāma pṛthak ahaṅkāra parityāgena namaskartavya mahima udghāṭanam sāmarasyam iti yāvat
translated: For salutation is the disclosure of the greatness of the object of salutation by relinquishing the separate sense of I, it is, in other words, a state of oneness.

analyzed: tathā hiyā iyam parā sā
translated: Thus, this supreme power is the power of the speaker.

analyzed: yā paśyantī sā udyukta tā
translated: The seeing power is the enthusiasm.

analyzed: yā tu madhyamā sā pravṛtta tā
translated: The middle power is the activity.

analyzed: yā punar vaikharī sā nirvāhaka tā iti
translated: The external power is the fulfillment.

analyzed: śaktimataḥ vaktuḥ eva svarūpam parā ādi śaktayaḥ
translated: The supreme power and the other powers are the very nature of the speaker who possesses power.

original: itthamimāṃ vācaṃ namaskṛtya nijānāṃ svenaiva praṇītānām alaṅkārasūtrāṇāṃ tātparyamucyate /
analyzed: ittham imām vācam namaskṛtya nijānām svena eva praṇītānām alaṅkāra sūtrāṇām tātparyam ucyate
translated: Having thus saluted this speech, the purport of the aphorisms on ornamentation composed by himself is stated.

analyzed: hṛdayam udghāṭyate
translated: The heart is opened.

analyzed: kena prakāreṇa
translated: By what method?

analyzed: vṛttyā vṛtti svarūpeṇa sandarbheṇa
translated: By commentary, in the form of commentary, in the text.

original: atha dhvanidarśanānusāreṇa prakāraṇaṃ praṇinīṣuḥ bhāmahodbhaṭādīnāṃ darśanasthitiṃ pūrvapakṣatveno panyasyatiiha hi tāvadbhāmahodbhaṭetyādinā
analyzed: atha dhvani darśana anusāreṇa prakāraṇam praṇinīṣuḥ bhāmaha udbhaṭa ādīnām darśana sthitim pūrvapakṣa tvena upanyasyati iha hi tāvat bhāmaha udbhaṭa ityādinā
translated: Now, wishing to compose the treatise in accordance with the doctrine of dhvani, Bhämaha, Udbhaṭa and others are presented as the prima facie view, beginning with Here, indeed, Bhämaha, Udbhaṭa and others...

analyzed: atrā iyam darśana sthiti diś
translated: This is the direction of the philosophical position here.

analyzed: kāvyam hi nāma viśiṣṭa śabda artha ātmakam  tatra arthaḥ vācyaḥ
translated: Poetry, indeed, consists of distinguished words and meanings.

analyzed: pratīyamānaḥ ca
translated: There, the meaning is the denoted and the suggested.

original: yathā bhama dhaṃmia vīsattho so suṇāo ajja mārio deṇa /
analyzed: yathā saḥ suṇāaḥ ajja mārio
translated: As the righteous man, well-instructed by the Brahmana, heard today from the sage.

original: golāṇai kaccha kuḍaṅga vāsiṇā daria sīheṇa //
analyzed: golāṇai kaccha kuḍaṅga vāsiṇā daria sīheṇa
translated: By the lion living in the forest of the Godavari river, the son of the king of the Kalingas.

analyzed: atra svairiṇī uktau śva bhaya nivṛttyā dhārmika bhramaṇa a vidhiḥ vācya tvena sthitaḥ
translated: Here, the statement of the independent woman, by the cessation of fear of the righteous man, the injunction of wandering is established as the denoted meaning.

analyzed: sākṣāt saṅketita tvena ā vyavadhāna pratītika tvāt
translated: Because of the cognition of direct indication without interruption.

analyzed: godāvarī tīre siṃha upalabdhyā bhramaṇa niṣedhaḥ tu pratīyamānaḥ
translated: But the prohibition of wandering by the perception of the lion on the banks of the Godavari river is the suggested meaning.

analyzed: vākya artha samanvaya samanantaram asaṅketita tvena pratīteḥ
translated: Because of the cognition of being non-denoted after the combination of the meaning of the sentence.

original: itthaṃ vācyavilakṣiṇaḥ pratīyamāno yor'thaḥ sa yathāyogaṃ rasavastvalaṅkārasvarūpeṇa
analyzed: ittham vācya vilakṣiṇaḥ pratīyamānaḥ yaḥ ṛthaḥ sa yathāyogam rasa vastu alaṅkāra svarūpeṇa
translated: Thus, the meaning that is suggested, which is different from the denoted meaning, is in the form of rasa, vastu, and alamkara, as appropriate.

original: triskandhaḥ san sacamatkāratvāt kavisaṃrambha gocaratvāt sahṛdayapratīti viśrāntiviṣayatvāñca kāvyātmā /
analyzed: tri skandhaḥ san sa camatkāra tvāt kavi saṃrambha gocara tvāt sahṛdaya pratīti viśrānti viṣaya tvāt kāvya ātmā
translated: Being threefold, it is the soul of poetry because of its delightful nature, because it is the object of the poet's effort, and because it is the object of the cognition of the connoisseur.

analyzed: tasya mādhurya ādayaḥ guṇāḥ śaurya ādi vat samavāya vṛttyā upakurvate
translated: Its qualities such as sweetness serve it by the relation of inherence, like valor and other qualities.

analyzed: upama ādayaḥ punar kaṭaka ādi tsaṃyoga tad vṛttyā iti dhvanya ācāryāḥ
translated: The figures of speech such as simile serve it by the relation of inherence, like bracelets and other ornaments, according to the teachers of dhvani.

analyzed: trividhaḥ pi pratīyamānaḥ vācya upaskāraka tvāt alaṅkāra kakṣyā eva iti anye
translated: Others say that even the threefold [suggestion] is only a part of ornamentation, because it helps the denoted [meaning].

analyzed: atha grantham avayavaśas vyākurmaḥ
translated: Now we shall explain the text section by section.

analyzed: iha kāvyamārge
translated: In this path of poetry,

analyzed: alaṅkāra pakṣa nikṣiptam manyante
translated: they consider it to be placed in the category of ornamentation.

analyzed: tattvam punar anyathā iti yāvat
translated: But the truth is otherwise, up to this extent.

analyzed: yat manyante tat sa viśeṣam āha tathā hi ityādinā
translated: To show what they consider, he says Thus, etc.

original: paryāyoktamaprastutapraśaṃsā samāsokti rākṣepaḥ vyājastutirupameyopamā ananvayaḥ ityādiṣu vastumātrameva pratīyate na tu rasālaṅkārau /
analyzed: paryāyoktam aprastuta praśaṃsā samāsoktiḥ rākṣepaḥ vyājastutiḥ upameyopamā ananvayaḥ ityādiṣu vastu mātram eva pratīyate na tu rasa alaṅkārau
translated: In [figures of speech] such as paryāyokta (periphrasis), aprastutapraśaṃsā (indirect praise), samāsokti (tautological statement), rākṣepa (insinuation), vyājastuti (indirect praise), upamyeupamā (simile on simile), ananvaya (non-simile), only the object is suggested, not rasa (sentiment) or alamkāra (ornamentation).

analyzed: vyañjanā vyāpārasya iha lakṣa ghaṇā mūla tvāt
translated: Because the operation of suggestion is the basis of definition here.
When definition is the basis, rasa (sentiment) and alamkāra (ornamentation) cannot be suggested.

analyzed: tatra pratīyamāna lasya arthasya prakāra antareṇa abhidhānam paryāyoktam
translated: Among them, paryāyokta (periphrasis) is the expression of the suggested meaning in another way.

analyzed: yat vakṣyati gamyasya api bhaṅgī antareṇa abhidhānam paryāya uktam iti
translated: As he will say: Paryāyokta is the expression of the suggested meaning in another way.

analyzed: yathā spṛṣṭāḥ tāḥ nandane śacyāḥ keśa saṃbhoga lālitāḥ
translated: For example: Those bunches of pārijāta flowers, which were enjoyed by Śacī's hair in Nandana,

analyzed: sa avagha jñam pārijātasya mañjaryaḥ yasya sainikaiḥ
translated: were plucked by the soldiers of that [king].

original: atra hayagrīvasya svargavijayaḥ sainikasāvaghajñapārijātamañjarī sparśalakṣaṇena kāryeṇa pratyāyyate /🔽sāmānyaviśeṣabhāvādīnāṃ sambandhena yadaprastutātprastutapratītiḥ seyamaprastutapraśaṃsā /
analyzed: atra hayagrīvasya svarga vijayaḥ sainika sāvagha jña pārijāta mañjarī sparśa lakṣaṇena kāryeṇa pratyāyyate  sāmānya viśeṣa bhāva ādīnām sambandhena yat aprastutāt prastuta pratītiḥ sā iyam aprastuta praśaṃsā
translated: Here, the conquest of heaven by Hayagriva is suggested by the effect characterized by the touch of the Pārijāta flower, which is not directly mentioned.🔽When there is an understanding of the relevant through the relation of generality and particularity, etc., of what is not directly mentioned, this is called indirect description.

original: yadvakṣyati aprastutātsāmānyaviśeṣabhāve kāryakāraṇabhāve sārūpye ca prastutapratītāvaprastutapraśaṃsā iti /
analyzed: yat vakṣyati aprastutāt sāmānya viśeṣa bhāve kārya kāraṇa bhāve sārūpye ca prastuta pratītau aprastuta praśaṃsā iti
translated: As he will say: In the understanding of the relevant through generality, particularity, relation of cause and effect, and similarity, of what is not directly mentioned, there is indirect description.

original: yathā taṇṇātthiṃ kiṃpi pahaṇo pakappiyaṃ jaṃ ṇa ṇiai gharaṇīe /
analyzed: yathā kiṃpi pahaṇo pakappiyam jam ṇa gharaṇīe
translated: As in: What is not there for the husband, even if imagined, is not known by the wife.

analyzed: aṇāvaraa gamaṇa sīlaḥ sa kāla pahiaḥ sa
translated: He, who is of the nature of constant movement, is a traveler on the path of time, is to be sustained.

original: kannāsti kimapi patyuḥ prakalpitaṃ yanna niyatigṛhiṇyā /
analyzed: kad nā asti kim api patyuḥ prakalpitam yat na niyati gṛhiṇyā
translated: What is not there for the husband, even if imagined, is not known by the wife, who is the controller of destiny.

analyzed: anavarata gamana śīlasya kāla pathikasya pātheyam
translated: He, who is of the nature of constant movement, is a traveler on the path of time, is to be sustained.

analyzed: iti cchrāyā
translated: Thus, Chhāyā.

original: atra anavaratagamanaśīlasya patyurnijagṛhiṇyā pātheyatvena yanna kalpitaṃ tadyathā nāsti /
analyzed: atra anavarata gamana śīlasya patyuḥ nija gṛhiṇyā pātheya tvena yat na kalpitam tat yathā na asti
translated: Here, what is not imagined by the wife, who is the controller of the husband, as being for his sustenance, is as if it does not exist.

original: tathā kālapathikasya pāthematvena yadakalpitaṃ tannāstītyatra kālaḥsava grasatīti sāmānyarūpādaprastutāt prastuto viśeṣātmā prahastavadhaḥ🔽viśeṣaṇāsāmyādaprastutor'tho yadavagamyate sā samāsoktiḥ /
analyzed: tathā kāla pathikasya pāthema tvena yat akalpitam tat na asti iti atra grasati iti sāmānya rūpāt aprastutāt prastutaḥ viśeṣa ātmā prahasta vadhaḥ  viśeṣaṇa asāmyāt aprastuta ūrthaḥ yat avagamyate sā samāsoktiḥ
translated: Similarly, in the case of the traveler, what is not imagined as the path is non-existent, and here time swallows it up. From the general form, which is not the subject, the specific form, the killing of Prahasta, which is the subject, is understood.🔽When a meaning that is not the subject is understood due to the similarity of qualifications, it is called samāsokti (poetic compression).

analyzed: yat vakṣyati viśeṣaṇa sāmyāt aprastutasya gamya tve samāsoktiḥ iti
translated: As he will say: When the unmentioned is understood due to the similarity of qualifications, it is samāsokti (poetic compression).

original: yathā upoḍharāgeṇa vilolatārakaṃ tathā gṛhītaṃ śaśinā niśāmukham /
analyzed: yathā upoḍha rāgeṇa vilola tārakam tathā gṛhītam śaśinā niśā mukham
translated: As in: The moon, with its rising passion, seized the night with its restless stars,

original: yathā samastaṃ timirāṃśukaṃ tayā puro 'pi rāgādgalitaṃ na lakṣyitam //
analyzed: yathā samastam timira aṃśukam tayā puras pi rāgāt galitam na lakṣyitam
translated: just as she, with passion, did not notice that her veil of darkness had completely fallen away in front of him.

original: atropoḍharāgatvādinā viśeṣaṇasāmyenāprastuto nāyakavṛttāntaḥ pratīyate /🔽uktasya vakṣyamāṇasya vā prākāraṇikasya viśeṣapratītyartham ābhāsato niṣedhanamākṣepaḥ /
analyzed: atra upoḍha rāga tva ādinā viśeṣaṇa sāmyena aprastutaḥ nāyaka vṛttāntaḥ pratīyate  uktasya vakṣyamāṇasya vā prākāraṇikasya viśeṣa pratīti artham ābhāsataḥ niṣedhanam ākṣepaḥ
translated: Here, the story of the hero, which is not the subject, is understood by the similarity of qualifications such as having rising passion.🔽Reproaching is the apparent negation for the purpose of understanding the particular of what is stated or what is to be stated.

original: yadvakṣyati uktavakṣyamāṇayoḥ prākaraṇikayorviśeṣapratītyarthaṃ niṣedhābhāsa ākṣepaḥ iti /🔽yathā bālagra/
analyzed: yat vakṣyati ukta vakṣyamāṇayoḥ prākaraṇikayoḥ viśeṣa pratīti artham niṣedha ābhāsaḥ ākṣepaḥ iti  yathā
translated: As he will say: Reproaching is the apparent negation for the purpose of understanding the particular of what is relevant and stated or to be stated.

original: ṇāhaṃ dūri tīe piosit ti ṇāmhavāvāro /
analyzed: ṇa aham dūri tīe ti
translated: As in: I am far away, but my beloved is near.

original: sā marai tujbhpha ayaso eaṃ dhaṃmakkharaṃ bhaṇimo //
analyzed: sā marai ayasaḥ eam dhaṃmakkharam bhaṇimaḥ
translated: She will die, your infamy, we speak this word of Dharma.

analyzed: dūti tasyāḥ na asmad vyāpāraḥ
translated: 'O messenger, I am not her beloved' is not our concern.

analyzed: sā mriyate tava ayaśaḥ etat dharma akṣaram bhaṇāmaḥ
translated: She will die, your infamy, we speak this word of Dharma.

original: iti cchrāyā ' atra 'nāhaṃ dītiti' dītitvaniṣedho viśiṣṭāsmi dūtītyavagamayati /🔽stutinindayoḥ nindāstutigamakatve vyājastutiḥ /
analyzed: iti cchrāyā atra na aham dītiti dīti tva niṣedhaḥ viśiṣṭā asmi dūtī iti avagamayati
translated: And in the Chhāyā, here 'I am not the messenger' negates being the messenger and conveys the meaning 'I am distinguished'.🔽When praise and blame convey blame and praise, it is indirect praise.

analyzed: yad vakṣyati stuti nindābhyām nindā stutyoḥ gamya tve vyāja stutiḥ iti
translated: As he will say: 'When blame and praise are conveyed by praise and blame, it is indirect praise.'

original: yathā he helājitabodhisattva vacasāṃ kiṃ vistaraistoyadhe/
analyzed: yathā he helā jita bodhisattva vacasām kim vistaraiḥ toyadhe
translated: As in: 'Hey, hey, you who have conquered the Bodhisattvas with your words, what is the use of elaborations?

translated: He shows the difference in objects with 'arrangement' etc.

analyzed: saṅghaṭana adharma aguṇā
translated: The qualities are the properties of arrangement.

analyzed: alaṅkārāḥ tu śabda artha dharmāḥ iti
translated: But the ornaments are the properties of word and meaning.

analyzed: tat idam api agambhīram iti bhāvaḥ
translated: This is also not profound, that is the idea.

original: guṇālaṅkārayośca svarūpata evātivibhinnatvāt /🔽tathāhiaṅgino rasasya dharmā guṇāḥ aṅgayoḥ śabdārthayostvalaṅkārāḥ /
analyzed: guṇa alaṅkārayoḥ ca svarūpataḥ eva ati vibhinna tvāt  tathā hi aṅginaḥ rasasya dharmāḥ guṇāḥ aṅgayoḥ śabda arthayoḥ tu alaṅkārāḥ
translated: And because the nature of qualities and ornaments is very different.🔽Thus, the qualities are the properties of rasa, the principal factor, like courage etc. of the self.

analyzed: guṇāḥ tu niyamena utkarṣa hetavaḥ alaṅkārāḥ tu aniyamena
translated: The ornaments are the properties of the subordinate factors, word and meaning.🔽And the qualities are invariably the causes of excellence, but the ornaments are not invariably so.

analyzed: guṇāḥ samavāyena vartante
translated: The qualities exist by inherence.

analyzed: alaṅkārāḥ tu saṃyogena
translated: But the ornaments exist by conjunction.

original: yadāha ye rasasyāṅgino dharmāḥ śauryādaya ivātmanaḥ /
analyzed: yat āha ye rasasya aṅginaḥ dharmāḥ śaurya ādayaḥ iva ātmanaḥ
translated: As it is said: Those that are the properties of rasa, the principal factor, like courage etc. of the self,

analyzed: utkarṣa hetavaḥ te syuḥ acala sthitayaḥ guṇāḥ
translated: should be the qualities, which are the causes of excellence, and are of unmoving nature.

analyzed: upakurvanti tam santam ye ṅga dvāreṇa jātucit
translated: Those that sometimes serve it by the door of the subordinate factors,

analyzed: hāra ādi vat alaṅkārāḥ te nuprāsa upamā ādayaḥ
translated: are the ornaments like necklace etc., such as alliteration, simile etc.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: itthaṃ ca sati alaṅkārāpekṣayā guṇeṣveva prakṛṣṭaḥ kāvyopaskāraḥ yadvadasphuṭaṭālaṅkāratve 'pi kāvyatvābhyupagamaḥ /
analyzed: ittham ca sati alaṅkāra apekṣayā guṇeṣu eva prakṛṣṭaḥ kāvya upaskāraḥ yadvat asphuṭa ṭa alaṅkāra tve pi kāvya tva abhyupagamaḥ
translated: And in this case, the most excellent aid to poetry lies in the qualities themselves, in relation to the ornaments, just as poetry is accepted even when the ornaments are not clear.

analyzed: na hi tadvat asphuṭa guṇa tve
translated: For it is not like that when the qualities are not clear.

analyzed: yat āha analaṅkṛtī punar kvāpi iti
translated: As has been said—‘And again, without ornaments, nowhere.’

analyzed: yat etat evaṃvidham guṇānām alaṅkārāṇām ca prādhānyam
translated: When this is so, the pre-eminence of the excellences and the ornaments,

analyzed: tatra api purātanānām dṛṣṭiḥ asamīcīnā iti āha tat evam alaṅkārāḥ eva iti
translated: there also the view of the ancients is not correct, he says—‘Thus, the ornaments alone.’

original: atha vakroktijīvitakārabhaṭṭanāyaka yoḥsaṃ dṛṣṭī sannikṛṣṭe dhvanidarśanasyetyabhiprāyeṇāha'vakroktijīvitakāraḥ punarityādinā /
analyzed: atha vakrokti jīvitakāra bhaṭṭanāyaka dṛṣṭī sannikṛṣṭe dhvani darśanasya iti abhiprāyeṇa āha vakrokti jīvitakāraḥ punar ityādinā
translated: Or, with the intention that the views of the authors of the Vākyālaṅkāras and the Bhāmahas are in agreement with the doctrine of dhvani, he says—‘The author of the Vākyālaṅkāras, again, etc.’

analyzed: vaidagdhya bhaṅgī bhaṇiti svabhāvām vaidagdhya prakāra upeta bhaṇiti svarūpām iti arthaḥ
translated: The nature of speech endowed with the mode of cleverness, the nature of speech endowed with the type of cleverness—this is the meaning.

analyzed: jīvitam uktavān iti alaṅkāra mātra durāgraha abhāvaḥ dyotitaḥ
translated: He has spoken of life—the absence of the wrong view of mere ornament is indicated.

original: anyo 'pi sārabhūtaḥ sūkṣmoṃ'śaḥ tena avadhārita ityabhiprāyeṇāhavyāpāraprādhānyaṃ ceti /
analyzed: sāra bhūtaḥ sūkṣma oṃśaḥ tena avadhāritaḥ iti abhiprāyeṇa āha vyāpāra prādhānyam ca iti
translated: With the intention that another subtle essence has also been determined by him, he says—‘And the pre-eminence of operation.’

analyzed: vyāpāraḥ rasa pratyāyana ātmā
translated: Operation is of the nature of the communication of rasa.

original: tasya prādhānyaṃ pratipede /🔽na punaḥ aprādhānasya alaṅkāramātrasyeti yāvat /
analyzed: tasya prādhānyam pratipede  na punar a prādhānasya alaṅkāra mātrasya iti yāvat
translated: He accepted its pre-eminence.🔽Not again of mere ornament which is not primary—this is the meaning.

analyzed: alaṅkārāḥ punar vācya kakṣyā eva asya saṃmatā iti āha abhidhā prakāra ityādi
translated: Ornaments are again accepted by him as being only in the domain of the expressed meaning—he says—‘By the types of denotation’ etc.

original: yaśca vastvalaṅkārarasarūpaḥ trividhaḥ pratīyamānor'thaḥ yatra vidyamāno 'pi tatpratyāyanalakṣaṇasya' vyāpārasyaiva prādhānyamasya matamityāhasatyapi
analyzed: yaḥ ca vastu alaṅkāra rasa rūpaḥ trividhaḥ pratīyamāna ūrthaḥ yatra tad pratyāyana lakṣaṇasya vyāpārasya eva prādhānyam asya matam iti āha sati api
translated: That object which is of three kinds, viz., expressed by denotation, suggested and manifested, and which is of the nature of the expressed meaning, the ornament and the sentiment, where, though existing, the predominance belongs to the operation called the indication of that, this is his opinion. He says:

analyzed: ca ityādi
translated: That which is suggested, which is of three kinds, namely, the entity, the ornament, and the sentiment, and which, though present, is of secondary importance, as the function of suggestion is primary. This is his opinion. He says Even when present, etc.

original: upacāro lakṣaṇāśrayaṇāṃ tadvakrateti avivakṣitavācyādi samastadhvaniḥ kaṭākṣitaḥ /
analyzed: upacāraḥ lakṣaṇa āśrayaṇām tad vakra tā iti avivakṣita vācya ādi samasta dhvaniḥ kaṭākṣitaḥ
translated: Upacāra is the basis of lakṣaṇā. That is its crookedness. All dhvani, where the denoted sense is not intended, is implied.

original: itthaṃ ca sati dhvanidarśanā detad darśanasyālpakobheda ityāha'kevalamuktivaicitryeti' /
analyzed: ittham ca sati dhvani darśanāt etat darśanasya alpakaḥ bhedaḥ iti āha kevala mukti vaicitrya iti
translated: And in this case, the difference between this view and the view of dhvani is slight. He says In mere variety of expression, etc.

analyzed: atha bhaṭṭanāyaka matam bhaṭṭanāyakena tu ityādi
translated: Now, the view of Bhatta Nayaka, etc.

analyzed: prauḍha uktyā abhyupagatasya iti  bhogaḥ iti sva kapola kalpitaḥ vyavahāraḥ prauḍhā uktiḥ tayā aṅgīkṛtasya iti arthaḥ
translated: By bold assertion, what is accepted, etc.🔽Bhoga is a usage imagined by one's own mind. That is bold assertion. The meaning is: of what is accepted by that.

original: idṛśasya vyañjanavyāpārasya kāvyātmatvaṃ kathayatā nyagbhāvitaśabdārtha svarūpo 'yaṃ vyāpārastasyaiva prādhānyamuktam /
analyzed: idṛśasya vyañjana vyāpārasya kāvya ātma tvam kathayatā nyagbhāvita śabdārtha sva rūpaḥ yam vyāpāraḥ tasya eva prādhānyam uktam
translated: Saying that such a function of suggestion is the soul of poetry, he has stated that this function, where the nature of words and meanings is subordinated, is primary.

original: sa ca vyāpāro laukiko na bhavatītyāhatatrāpyabhidhābhāvaka tvetyādi /
analyzed: sa ca vyāpāraḥ laukikaḥ na bhavati iti āha tatra api abhidhā bhāvaka tva ityādi
translated: And that function is not worldly. He says Even there, in denotation and suggestion, etc.

analyzed: tatra teṣu vyāpāreṣu madhyāt abhidhā bhāvaka tve iti
translated: Among those operations, the primary one is the power of denotation and the power of suggestion.

analyzed: sākṣāt saṅketa artha viṣayā śaktiḥ abhidhā
translated: The power of denotation is the power that directly conveys the meaning of a convention.

analyzed: asādhāraṇyena pratīteṣu artheṣu sādhāraṇīkaraṇa rūpā śaktiḥ bhāvika tvam
translated: The power of suggestion is the power that makes common what is uncommon among objects that are cognized as uncommon.

original: etadvyāpāradvaradvayot tīrṇaḥ sādhāraṇīkṛteṣu vibhāvādiṣu rasacarvaṇātmāṃ bhogāparanāmadheyo vyāpāro viśrāntisthānatayā prādhanyenāṅgīkṛtaḥ
analyzed: etad vyāpāra dvara dvaya ud tīrṇaḥ sādhāraṇīkṛteṣu vibhāva ādiṣu rasa carvaṇa ātmām bhoga apara nāmadheyaḥ vyāpāraḥ viśrānti sthāna tayā prādhanyena aṅgīkṛtaḥ
translated: The operation that is named as enjoyment, which is the relishing of rasa in the vibhāvas and other factors that have been made common, is accepted as the primary one by being the resting place, transcending these two pairs of operations.

analyzed: atra darśane bhoga ādi vyāvahārasya sva kapola kalpita vyāpāra prādhānyam iti aṃśaḥ dhvanikāra darśana vilakṣaṇāḥ
translated: In this view, the part where the usage of enjoyment etc. is the primary operation imagined by one's own mind is different from the view of Dandin.

analyzed: atha siddha antar dhvani kāraḥ punar ityādi
translated: Now, the conclusion is stated by Dandin with Dandin, on the other hand... etc.

analyzed: dhvanikāraḥ tu vyaṅgya ātmanaḥ vākyārthasya eva kāvya ātma tvam siddhāntitavān
translated: Dandin, on the other hand, has established that the essence of poetry lies in the suggested meaning itself, which is the meaning of a sentence.

analyzed: tatra ha idatuḥ vyañjana vyāpārasya avaśya abhyupagamya tvāt iti
translated: There, he has given the reason as because the operation of suggestion must necessarily be accepted.

analyzed: kīdṛśasya abhidhā lakṣaṇā tātparya ākhya vyāpāra traya uttīrṇasya
translated: What kind of [suggested meaning]? That which transcends the three operations called denotation, indication, and persuasion.

analyzed: tātparya nāma padārtha adhigama samanantara bhāvinī samanvaya śaktiḥ
translated: Persuasion is the power of connection that arises immediately after the cognition of the meanings of words.

analyzed: etat traya uttīrṇasya iti
translated: And the statement of one who has gone beyond these three is made in the fourth box.

analyzed: dhvanana dyotana iti
translated: Dhvāna means illumination.

original: dhvananaṃ dyotanaṃ pratyāyanaṃ vyañjanamityādiprasiddhaparyāyasahatastrasyāvaśyābhyupagamyatvāt tadanabhyupagame vyaṅgyārthapratītau na gatyantaraṃ
analyzed: dhvananam dyotanam pratyāyanam vyañjanam ityādi prasiddha paryāya sahata strasya avaśya abhyupagamya tvāt tad anabhyupagame vyaṅgya artha pratītau na gati antaram
translated: Since dhvanana (suggestion), dyotana (illumination), pratyāyana (indication), vyañjana (expression), etc. are well-known synonyms, and must be accepted, there is no other way to understand the suggested meaning if they are not accepted.

analyzed: atas vyaṅgyaḥ ṛthaḥ eva ātmā iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the suggested meaning itself is the soul. This is the meaning.

original: nanu vyañjanāvyāpāraḥ pradhānaṃ kiṃ na bhavati /
analyzed: nanu vyañjanā vyāpāraḥ pradhānam kim na bhavati
translated: But is the operation of suggestion not the primary [factor]?

analyzed: iti atas āha vyāpārasya ca vākya artha tva abhāvāt iti
translated: To this he says: And because the operation is not the meaning of the sentence.

analyzed: apratyakṣa tvena nirukti anarha tvāt vākya artha tva abhāvaḥ
translated: It is not the meaning of the sentence because it is not perceptible or because it is not fit to be defined.

original: sarvā eva khalu padārthaśaktayaḥ kāryādipratītyanyathānupapattyā abhyūhyanta eva /
analyzed: sarvāḥ eva khalu padārtha śaktayaḥ kārya ādi pratīti anyathā anupapattyā abhyūhyante eva
translated: In fact, all the potencies of word meanings are inferred only by the impossibility of understanding the effect, etc. in any other way.

analyzed: atas vyāpāraḥ na prādhānam
translated: Therefore, the operation is not primary.

original: yaśca hetuḥ prādhānye so 'pi vyaṅgya evopapadyate /
analyzed: yaḥ ca hetuḥ prādhānye saḥ pi vyaṅgyaḥ eva upapadyate
translated: And the reason for primacy is also logically possible only in the suggested meaning,

analyzed: na tu vyañjana vyāpāraḥ iti āha vākya arthasya eva iti
translated: but not in the operation of suggestion. He says: Of the meaning of the sentence itself.

analyzed: guṇa alaṅkāra upaskarttavya tvam viśrānti sthāna tvam ca prādhānye hetuḥ
translated: Being subordinate to the qualities and ornaments, and being the resting place, are the reasons for primacy.

analyzed: atas vyaṅgya arthaḥ eva kāvya ātmā iti siddhāntitavan
translated: Therefore, it is established that the suggested meaning alone is the soul of poetry.

analyzed: atha bhūyastarāḥ yuktīḥ abhyuccinoti vyāpārasya viṣaya mukhena ityādi
translated: Now he selects the most important figures of speech, beginning with the activity of suggestion, through the medium of the suggested meaning.

analyzed: vyāpārasya vyaṅyā artha mukhena eva svarūpa siddhiḥ
translated: The form of the activity of suggestion is established only through the medium of the suggested meaning.

analyzed: atas na vākya artha tva saṃbhavaḥ
translated: Therefore, it cannot be the meaning of a sentence.

original: yathāsvarūpopalambho viṣayamukhena tathā prādhānyaṃ vicārakṣamatvamapi tanmukhenaivetyāhatatprādhānyena prādhānyāt /
analyzed: yathā sva rūpa upalambhaḥ viṣaya mukhena tathā prādhānyam vicāra kṣamatvam api tad mukhena eva iti āha tad prādhānyena prādhānyāt
translated: Just as the apprehension of its own form is through the medium of the object, so too its primacy and capacity for consideration are only through that medium. He says by its primacy, due to primacy.

analyzed: svarūpeṇa vicārya tva abhāvāt iti ca
translated: And because there is no consideration by its own form.

original: viṣaya eva tu puṣkalaṃ vākyārthaṃ bhāvamarhatītyāhaviṣayasyaiveti /
analyzed: viṣayaḥ eva tu puṣkalam vākya artham bhāvam arhati iti āha viṣayasya eva iti
translated: But the object alone deserves to be the principal meaning of a sentence. He says of the object alone.

original: sākṣātsvarūpa pratilaṃbhaḥ svataḥ prādhānyaṃ svalarūpeṇa vicāryatvaṃ cetyādi samagre bharaḥ /
analyzed: sākṣāt svarūpa pratilaṃbhaḥ svatas prādhānyam ca ityādi samagre bharaḥ
translated: The entire burden of direct apprehension of its own form, primacy by itself, and consideration by its own form, etc.

analyzed: tad sahiṣṇu tvam hi vyāṅgya artha lakṣaṇasya viśaṣayasya eva
translated: Belongs to the object alone, which is characterized by the suggested meaning.

analyzed: atas viṣayasya eva ātma tvam yuktam iti āha tasmāt viṣayaḥ eva iti
translated: Therefore, it is proper that the object alone should be the soul. He says therefore, the object alone.

original: samagrabhara sahiṣṇutvāt sa niravaśeṣavaibhavamarhatītyata āhayasya guṇālaṅkāretyādi /
analyzed: samagra bhara sahiṣṇu tvāt sa niravaśeṣa vaibhavam arhati iti atas āha yasya guṇa alaṅkāra ityādi
translated: Because of its ability to bear the entire burden, it deserves all the glory. Therefore it is said: Whose qualities and ornaments...

original: nanu rasādayo rasavadādyālaṅkārā eva prācāṃ matāḥ /
analyzed: nanu rasa ādayaḥ rasavat ādya alaṅkārāḥ eva prācām matāḥ
translated: But rasa and others are considered by the ancients to be only the figures of rasa and others.

analyzed: katham eṣām alaṅkārya tvam iti atas āha rasa ādayaḥ tu iti
translated: How then are they to be embellished? To this he says rasa and others...

original: tatra hetuḥ alaṅkārāṇāmupaskārakatvāt rasādīnāṃ ca prādhānyenopaskāryatvācca iti /
analyzed: tatra hetuḥ alaṅkārāṇām upaskāraka tvāt rasa ādīnām ca prādhānyena upaskārya tvāt ca iti
translated: The reason there is because the figures are supplementary and because rasa and others are to be supplemented as primary.

analyzed: rasa ādīnām hi yadā guṇībhāvaḥ tadā alaṅkāra tvam
translated: For when rasa and others are subordinate, then they are figures.

analyzed: yadā tu prādhānyam tadā alaṅkārya tvam eva
translated: But when they are primary, then they are to be embellished.

analyzed: yatas ittham vyavasthā
translated: Since the arrangement is thus,

original: atoḥ vyaṅgyārtha eva kāvyātmeti nigamayati tasmād vyaṅgya evetyādi /
analyzed: atoḥ vyaṅgya arthaḥ eva kāvya ātmā iti nigamayati tasmāt vyaṅgyaḥ eva ityādi
translated: therefore the suggested meaning alone is the soul of poetry. This is concluded by Therefore, the suggested meaning alone...

analyzed: vākya arthībhūtaḥ iti prādhānya daśām kaṭākṣayati
translated: Having become the meaning of the sentence indicates the state of being primary.

analyzed: daśāyām anātma tvāt
translated: In the state of being non-primary, it is not the soul.

original: tadidaṃ dhvanikṛto darśanām /🔽etadanusāritvamātmano darśayutumāha eṣa eva pakṣa ityādi /
analyzed: tat idam dhvanikṛtaḥ darśanām  etad anusāri tvam ātmanaḥ darśa yutum āha eṣaḥ eva pakṣaḥ ityādi
translated: This is shown by the author of Dhvanyāloka.🔽To show that he follows this view, he says This position alone... and so on.

analyzed: eva kāreṇa pakṣa antareṣu anupapattiḥ āviśaṣkriyate
translated: By the word alone, the impossibility in other positions is indicated.

analyzed: āvarjakaḥ balāt ātma abhimukhīkārakaḥ
translated: Attracting means forcibly turning the soul towards itself.

analyzed: tatra hetuḥ vyañjana vyāpārasya ityādi
translated: The reason for this is stated beginning with the operation of denotation.

analyzed: ye vyaṅgya arthasya kāvya ātma tām
translated: Those who desire the essence of poetry to be the suggested meaning,

analyzed: ye ca na icchanti
translated: and those who do not desire it,

original: sarvaireva khalvebhiḥ na śakyate hi vyañjanavyāpāro 'pahnotum /
analyzed: sarvaiḥ eva khalu ebhiḥ na śakyate hi vyañjana vyāpāraḥ upahnotum
translated: by all of them indeed the operation of denotation cannot be denied.

original: yadi nāpahnutaḥ kiṃ tata ityata āhatadāśrayaṇe cetyādi /
analyzed: yadi na apahnutaḥ kim tatas iti atas āha tad āśrayaṇe ca ityādi
translated: If it is not denied, what follows from that? To this he says and in its dependence and so on.

analyzed: pakṣa antarasya apratiṣṭhānam darśaitacarībhiḥ yuktibhiḥ siddham
translated: The non-establishment of an alternative view is shown by the established logical reasons.

original: yattu tatra vyaktivivekakāraḥ pratyavasthaitaḥ tadupanyasyati yattu vyaktivivekakāraḥ ityādinā /
analyzed: yat tu tatra vyakti viveka kāraḥ tat upanyasyati yat tu vyakti viveka kāraḥ ityādinā
translated: But what the author of the Vyaktiviveka objects to there, he presents with But what the author of the Vyaktiviveka and so on.

analyzed: liṅga tayā gamaka tayā
translated: As the indicative, as the conveyor.

analyzed: tādātmya tad utpatti abhāvāt iti
translated: Because of the absence of identity and origination from that.

analyzed: dharma dharmiṇoḥ liṅga liṅgi bhāve tādātmyam nāma niyataḥ sambandhaḥ
translated: In the case of the relation of the property-possessor and the property, the relation called identity is a definite relation.

analyzed: kārya kāraṇāyoḥ tu tad abhāve tad utpattiḥ nāma asti iti
translated: But in the case of cause and effect, when that is absent, there is origination from that.

original: anayorniyatasambandhayoḥ yadyanyataro na syāt tadā vyabhicārānna saṃbhavati liṅgaliṅgibhāva iti yāvat /
analyzed: anayoḥ niyata sambandhayoḥ yadi anyataraḥ na syāt tadā vyabhicārāt na saṃbhavati liṅga liṅgi bhāvaḥ iti yāvat
translated: Of these two definite relations, if one were not to exist, then due to the fallacy of non-apprehension, the relation of the indicative and the property-possessor would not be possible, that is the extent of it.

analyzed: yatas ittham etat atas tat avicārita abhidhānam
translated: Since it is so, therefore that is an expression without consideration.

original: tadetadvyaktivivekakṛto darśanaṃ vāyasavāśitakalpamiti yāvat /🔽evaṃ dhvanidarśanasamarthane yadyāvadasti yuktijātaṃ tadatigahanam /
analyzed: tat etat vyakti viveka kṛtaḥ darśanam vāyasa vāśita kalpam iti yāvat  evam dhvani darśana samarthane yat yāvat asti yukti jātam tat ati gahanam
translated: This view, which is based on the distinction of the manifest, is like the cawing of a crow.🔽Thus, in the defense of the theory of dhvani, as much as there is a collection of reasons, it is very profound.

analyzed: dhvani guṇībhūta vyaṅgyayoḥ eva kāvyayoḥ mīmāṃsāyām upayujyate
translated: It is useful in the investigation of only those two types of poetry where the suggested sense is subordinated to the expressed sense.

original: citrakāvyamīmāṃsāyāṃ tu nātyupayujyate ityāśayena nigamayititadetat kuśāgrīyetyādi /
analyzed: citrakāvyamīmāṃsāyām tu na atyupayujyate iti āśayena kuśāgrīya ityādi
translated: But in the investigation of ornate poetry, it is not very useful. With this idea in mind, he concludes with That is this... etc.

analyzed: iha citrakāvye
translated: Here, in ornate poetry.

analyzed: na pratanyate  yathopayogam anūdyataḥ eva iti yāvat
translated: It is not extended.🔽It is referred to only as much as is useful.

analyzed: atha yāvān upayogaḥ citra prastāve dhvaneḥ tāvat mātram anuvadati asti tāvat ityādinā
translated: Now, as much as is useful in the context of the ornate, he repeats just that much regarding dhvani, with There is, after all... etc.

original: yadyasti kiṃ tata ityata āhatatra vyaṅgyasyetyādi /
analyzed: yadi asti kim tatas iti atas āha tatra vyaṅgyasya ityādi
translated: If there is, what then? To this he says There, of the suggested sense... etc.

analyzed: prādhānye dhvaniḥ namaḥ uttamaḥ kāvya bhedaḥ
translated: When it is primary, it is the highest type of poetry called dhvani.

analyzed: aprādhānye tu madhyamaḥ
translated: But when it is not primary, it is the middle type called guṇībhūtavyaṅgya.

analyzed: citrasya viṣayam āha tatra uttamaḥ dhvaniḥ ityādinā
translated: He states the subject matter of the ornate with There, the highest is dhvani... etc.

original: sa cābhidhāmūlatayā lakṣaṇāmūlatayā ca prathate ityāhatasya lakṣaṇābhidhāmūlatveneti /
analyzed: sa ca abhidhā mūla tayā lakṣaṇā mūla tayā ca prathate iti āhatasya lakṣaṇa abhidhā mūla tvena iti
translated: And that is known as based on denotation and based on indication, he says Its being based on indication and denotation... etc.

original: lakṣaṇāmūlatve sati avivakṣita vācyākhyaḥ mukhyārthabādhaśālinyāṃ lakṣaṇāyāṃ vācyāṃśasyāvivakṣitatvāt /
analyzed: lakṣaṇā mūla tve sati avivakṣita vācya ākhyaḥ mukhya artha bādha śālinyām lakṣaṇāyām vācya aṃśasya avivakṣita tvāt
translated: When based on secondary signification, it is called 'having the expressed meaning not intended', because in secondary signification, which is characterized by the contradiction of the primary meaning, the expressed portion is not intended.

analyzed: abhidhā mūla tve tu vivakṣita anya para vācya ākhyaḥ
translated: But when based on denotation, it is called 'having the expressed meaning intended but referring to something else'.

analyzed: abhidhāyām vācye bādhā abhāvāt vivakṣita tvam
translated: Because there is no contradiction of the expressed meaning in denotation, it is intended.

original: vyaṅgyāṅgatvena vivakṣaṇāt anyaparatā ceti vivakṣitānyaparatvam abhidhāmūlasya /
analyzed: vyaṅgya aṅga tvena vivakṣaṇāt anya para tā ca iti vivakṣita anya para tvam abhidhā mūlasya
translated: And because it is intended as a subordinate element of the suggested meaning, it refers to something else. Thus, having the expressed meaning intended but referring to something else is based on denotation.

analyzed: ittham lakṣaṇā mūlaḥ bhidhā mūlaḥ ca iti sāmānyatas dhvaniḥ dvirāśikaḥ  tatra lakṣaṇā mūlasya avāntarabhedam āha ādyaḥ ūrthantaraḥ iti
translated: Thus, suggestion is of two kinds in general: based on secondary signification and based on denotation.

analyzed: ādyaḥ lakṣaṇā mūlaḥ saḥ ṛtha antara saṅkramita vācyaḥ atyanta tiraskṛta vācyaḥ ca iti dvidhā
translated: Among them, he states the subdivisions of that based on secondary signification: The first is based on secondary signification. It is twofold: having the expressed meaning transferred to another meaning and having the expressed meaning completely set aside.

original: ajahatsvārthatayā svasiddhaye parākṣepe sati arthāntarasaṅkramitavācyaḥ /🔽yathā prārambhe śrutisundaraṃ pariṇātau pathyaṃ janaiḥsugrahaṃ /
analyzed: a jahat sva artha tayā sva siddhaye parākṣepe sati artha antara saṅkramita vācyaḥ  yathā prārambhe śruti sundaram pariṇātau pathyam janaiḥ sugraham
translated: When there is transference of one's own meaning to establish another, it is having the expressed meaning transferred to another meaning.🔽For example, at the beginning, pleasing to the ear, nourishing to people at the end, easy to grasp.

analyzed: nānā śāstra rasaiḥ prasanna madhuraiḥ pratyakṣaram kṣālitam
translated: Purified with every syllable by the clear and sweet juices of various scriptures,

original: āhlādāya na kasya nāma viduṣāṃ vaktrāmbujādudgataṃ cittāntarvikasadviveka mukulāmodānubiddhaṃ vacaḥ //
analyzed: āhlādāya na kasya nāma viduṣām vaktra ambujāt udgatam citta antar vikasat viveka mukula āmoda anubiddham vacaḥ
translated: Does not the speech of the wise, which arises from the lotus of their mouths, delight everyone, being filled with the joy of discrimination blossoming in the mind?

analyzed: atra evaṃvidha vacaḥ upadeśa alakṣaṇe artha antare saṅkrāmati
translated: Here, such speech is transferred to a different meaning, not characterized by instruction.

analyzed: vacaḥ mātrasya evam vaiśiṣṭya asaṃbhavāt
translated: Because such a distinction is not possible for mere speech.

original: atha yadā jahatsvārthatayā parārthaṃ svasamarpaṇaṃ tadātyantatiraskṛtavācyākhyaḥ /
analyzed: atha yadā jahat svārtha tayā parārtham sva samarpaṇam tadā atyanta tiraskṛta vācya ākhyaḥ
translated: Now, when it is dedicated to others by abandoning its own meaning, then it is called extremely suppressed in denotation.

original: yathā eke mūkavadāsate jaḍadhiyo jihneti tatsannidhā vanye durviciktsitaṃ vidadhate tebhyo 'pi bībhatsate /
analyzed: yathā eke mūka vat āsate jaḍa dhiyaḥ jihnā iti tad sannidhā vanye durviciktsitam vidadhate tebhyaḥ pi bībhatsate
translated: For example, some remain like dumb people, those with dull intellects speak like the lame nearby, they are even more disgusted than those who engage in difficult reflection.

original: asthāne bahudhā stuvanti katicittairulkayā dahyate vidyā viklavate kayā na vidhayā prāpyāntikaṃ duṣprabhoḥ //
analyzed: asthāne bahudhā stuvanti katicid taiḥ ulkayā dahyate vidyā viklavate kayā na vidhayā prāpya antikam duṣprabhoḥ
translated: Some praise excessively in the wrong place, by some they are burned with a torch, by what kind of misfortune does knowledge become confused upon reaching the presence of the wicked lord?

original: atra vidyāyāṃ hlībībhatsādiḥ gaṅgādau ghoṣādhikaraṇatādīva sarvathā svasaṃyogino svārthaṃ parityajya na saṃbhavatītyatyanta tiraskṛtavācyatā
analyzed: atra vidyāyām hlī bībhatsa ādiḥ gaṅgā ādau ghoṣa adhikaraṇa tā ādi iva sarvathā sva saṃyoginā sva artham parityajya na saṃbhavati iti atyanta tiraskṛta vācya tā
translated: Here, disgust etc. towards knowledge, and the state of having the sound of the Ganges etc., are not possible in any way by abandoning their own meaning associated with themselves, so it is extremely suppressed in denotation.

analyzed: ittham a vivakṣita vācyasya artha antara saṃkramita vācya utyanta tiraskṛta vācyaḥ ca iti dvau bhedau
translated: Thus, the suggested sense is of two kinds: that which is transferred to another sense and that which is utterly suppressed.
Now, the direction of the division based on denotation.

analyzed: dvitīyaḥ pi iti
translated: The second also.
The second, based on denotation, is called having a different sense than intended.

original: tatra kvicid vyaṅgya kramo na saṃlakṣyate /
analyzed: tatra kvicid vyaṅgya kramaḥ na saṃlakṣyate
translated: In that, the sequence of the suggested sense is not noticed in some cases.

analyzed: kvacid saṃlakṣyate
translated: In some cases, it is noticed.

analyzed: tasmāt vivakṣita anya para vācyaḥ asaṃlakṣya krama vyaṅgyaḥ saṃlakṣya krama vyaṅgyaḥ ca iti dvividhaḥ
translated: Therefore, even the one having a different sense than intended is of two kinds: with the sequence of the suggested sense not noticed and with the sequence of the suggested sense noticed.

original: athānayoḥ sakṣaṇābhidhāmūladhvanyorvastvalaṅkāra rasarūpatā viṣayaviśeṣaṃ vyavasthāpayitumāhalakṣaṇāmūla ityādinā /🔽yo hi lakṣaṇāmūlaḥ sa niyameva śabdaśaktimūlo vasturūpaśca bhavati /
analyzed: atha anayoḥ sakṣaṇa abhidhā mūla dhvanyoḥ vastvalaṅkāra rasa rūpatā viṣaya viśeṣam vyavasthāpayitum āha lakṣaṇā mūlaḥ ityādinā  yaḥ hi lakṣaṇā mūlaḥ sa niyamā iva śabda śakti mūlaḥ vastu rūpaḥ ca bhavati
translated: Now, in order to establish the difference in subject matter of these two types of dhvani based on denotation and indication, he says based on indication and so on.🔽For that which is based on indication is necessarily based on the power of the word and is of the nature of substance.

original: yadvi yāvadasti jātiguṇākriyādyātmākaṃ padārthajātaṃ sarvamevaitadvastu kathyate /
analyzed: yat vi yāvat asti jāti guṇa akriyā ādi ātmākam padārtha jātam sarvam eva etat vastu kathyate
translated: Whatever exists, in the form of genus, quality, action, etc., all this is called substance.

analyzed: tat eva kavi kalpita vicchitti sadhrīcīnam alaṅkāraḥ
translated: That very thing, along with the arrangement imagined by the poet, is ornamentation.

analyzed: rasāḥ tu rati ādayaḥ sahṛdaya pratīti viśeṣāḥ
translated: The rasas are the emotions such as love, etc., which are manifested by the vibhāvas, anubhāvas, and vyabhicāribhāvas, and are the special feelings of the connoisseur.

original: atha vivakṣitānyaparavācyo yo 'yaṃ asaṃlakṣyakramavyaṅgyaḥ sa niyamenārthaśaktimūla ubhayaśaktimūlaśca bhavati /
analyzed: atha vivakṣita anya para vācyaḥ yaḥ yam asaṃlakṣya krama vyaṅgyaḥ sa niyamena artha śakti mūlaḥ ubhaya śakti mūlaḥ ca bhavati
translated: Now, this rasa which is not manifested by a perceptible order of sequence and is denoted by words having a different intended meaning, is necessarily based on the power of the meaning and the power of both [the word and the meaning].

analyzed: niyamena vastu rūpaḥ laṅkāra rūpaḥ ca bhavati
translated: It is necessarily of the nature of substance and of the nature of ornament.

original: tatra yadā rasabhāvarasābhāsa bhāvābhāsabhāvodayabhāvaśānti bhāvasandhibhāvaśabalatā vyajyante /
analyzed: tatra yadā
translated: There, when rasa, bhāva, rasābhasa, bhāvābhāsa, bhāvodaya, bhāvaśānti, bhāvasandhi, and bhāvaśabalatā are manifested,

original: tadā kramo na saṃlakṣyata iti asaṃlakṣyakramatvam /
analyzed: tadā kramaḥ na saṃlakṣyate iti asaṃlakṣya krama tvam
translated: then the order is not perceived, so it is called not having a perceptible order of sequence.

original: tatra raseṣu śṛṅgāraḥsaṃbhogātmā yathā puṣpodbhedamavāpya keliśayanāddarasthayā cumbane kāntena sphuritādhareṇa nibhṛtaṃ bhrūsaṃjñayā yācite
analyzed: tatra raseṣu śṛṅgāraḥ saṃbhoga ātmā yathā puṣpa udbhedam avāpya keli śayanāt dara sthayā cumbane kāntena sphurita adhareṇa nibhṛtam bhrū saṃjñayā yācite
translated: There, in the rasas, the erotic love which has the nature of enjoyment is like this: Having attained the blossoming of flowers, the young woman, lying on the bed of love, is kissed by her lover with trembling lower lip, requested with a gesture of the eyebrows.

original: ācchādya smitapūrṇā gaṇḍaphalakaṃ celāñcalenānanaṃ mandāndolitakuṇḍalastabakayā tanvyā vidhūtaṃ śiraḥ //
analyzed: ācchādya smita pūrṇā gaṇḍa phalakam cela añcalena ānanam manda āndolita kuṇḍala stabakayā tanvyā vidhūtam śiraḥ
translated: The slender lady covers her face with the hem of her garment, full of smiles on her cheeks, and shakes her head with a garland of earrings swaying gently.

original: atra nāyikānāyakavṛttāntalakṣaṇo yo vācyor'thaḥ yā ca sahṛdayapratīteḥ vedyāntaravigalanena varṇyavastutanmayībhāvalakṣaṇā rasasaṃvit /
analyzed: atra nāyikā nāyaka vṛttānta lakṣaṇaḥ yaḥ vācya arthaḥ yā ca sahṛdaya pratīteḥ vedya antara vigalanena varṇya vastu tanmayībhāva lakṣaṇā rasa saṃvid
translated: Here, the expressed meaning, which is characterized by the story of the heroine and hero, and the experience of rasa, which is characterized by the absorption in the described object due to the disappearance of the other knowable through the understanding of the connoisseur,

analyzed: na khalu tayoḥ kramaḥ saṃlakṣyate
translated: the sequence of these two is not perceived.

analyzed: vidyamānaḥ pi padma patra śata vyatibheda nayena a vidyamāna vat upalakṣyate
translated: Even though present, it is perceived as if absent, like the piercing of a hundred lotus petals.

original: vipralambhaśṛṅgāro yathā nāntaḥ praveśamaruṇādvimukhī na cāsī dācaṣṭaroṣa paruṣāṇi na cākṣarāṇi /
analyzed: vipralambha śṛṅgāraḥ yathā na antar praveśam aruṇāt vimukhī na ca asī paruṣāṇi na ca akṣarāṇi
translated: The sentiment of love in separation, as in: She did not enter the house, nor did she turn away from the ruddy dawn, nor did she utter harsh words.

original: sā kevalaṃ saralapakṣmabhirakṣipātaiḥ kāntaṃ vilokitavatī jananirviśeṣam //
analyzed: sā kevalam sarala pakṣmabhiḥ akṣipātaiḥ kāntam vilokitavatī jana nirviśeṣam
translated: O Mother! She merely looked at her lover with eyes having innocent eyelashes, like an ordinary woman.

analyzed: evamādiṣu akrama tvam prāgvat anusandheyam
translated: In such cases, the lack of sequence should be understood as before.

original: hāsyo yathā paimaraṇāmaṇḍaṇājjalavesā pāsaṃga esu taruṇesu /
analyzed: hāsyaḥ yathā taruṇesu
translated: The sentiment of mirth, as in: In the assembly of young men, she, adorned with the ornaments of her husband's death,

original: ṇiddhasaraṃ parugrantī savibbhamaṃ haṇā i thaṇāvaṭṭham //
analyzed: ṇiddhasaram sa vibbhamam haṇā i thaṇāvaṭṭham
translated: with a moist voice, suddenly and with confusion, placed her breasts on his chest.

original: atra patimaraṇāmaṇḍanojjvalaveṣāyāḥ taruṇeṣu pārśvamupagateṣu satsu sadyaḥ snigdhasvaraṃprarudatyāḥ
analyzed: atra pati maraṇa āmaṇḍana ujjvala veṣāyāḥ taruṇeṣu pārśvam upagateṣu satsu sadyas snigdha svaram prarudatyāḥ
translated: Here, she, resplendent with the ornaments of her husband's death, when young men approached her side, suddenly wept with a moist voice,

analyzed: sa vibhramam yat etat stana vṛtta hananam tat pracchanna anurāgasya anaucityena pravṛtteḥ hāsyam abhivyanakti
translated: The act of striking the round breasts with a playful manner expresses laughter due to the impropriety of engaging in love with concealed affection.

original: karuṇasya yathā sāhityalakṣaṇakale samupaiṣi navya vaidhavyamadya virate guruviṣṇudeve /
analyzed: karuṇasya yathā sāhitya lakṣaṇa kale samupaiṣi navya vaidhavyam adya virate guru viṣṇu deve
translated: Of pathos, as in the following verse of the Sahityalaksana: Today, O new widow, you have attained widowhood, with the passing away of your husband Guruvisnudeva.

analyzed: karṇa antika praṇāyana praṇāya utsavāya tālī dala arpaṇam itas param akṣamam te
translated: From now on, it is not proper for you to offer palm leaves for the sake of the festival of bringing near the ear.

original: raudranya yathā dṛpyatsūkara kālakaṇṭha śakalavyākīrṇa dhārāntarā krodhottālalulāyakaṇṭhanalakacchedārdhavaktrānanāḥ /
analyzed: yathā
translated: Of the terrible, as in the following: O boar, with your throat torn apart by the pieces of the Kalakuta poison, with your neck and throat cut off by the violently agitated tongue, with your face half-chewed,

original: śrīballāla vidhāya keli mṛgayāmāvartamānasya te śārdūlendravasābhiṣekasamaye jīyāsurugrāḥśarāḥ //
analyzed: śrī ballāla vidhāya keli mṛgayām āvartamānasya te śārdūla indra vasā abhiṣeka samaye jīyāsuḥ ugrāḥ śarāḥ
translated: while you are engaged in the sport of hunting, O King Ballala, may your fierce arrows survive at the time of anointing with the fat of the lion king.

original: vīrasya yathā ādhāturbhuvanaṃ tadetadakhilaṃ cakṣuṣmadākīṭakād divyaṃ cakṣurananyalabhya mubhayatrāste paraṃ duḥsaham /
analyzed: vīrasya yathā ādhātuḥ bhuvanam tat etat akhilam cakṣuṣmat ākīṭakāt divyam cakṣuḥ an anya labhyam ubhayatra āste param duḥsaham
translated: Of the heroic, as in the following: That eye of the Creator, which is the divine eye, difficult to obtain elsewhere, exists in both, in order to create this entire world, in the worm with eyes, and in the man with eyes.

original: phāle bhūtapatermanobhavamukha kṣudra kṣayojjāgaraṃ bāṇe ca pratirājadarpadalanaṃ ballāla pṛthvīpateḥ //
analyzed: phāle bhūtapateḥ manobhava mukha kṣudra kṣaya ujjāgaram bāṇe ca pratirāja darpa dalanam ballāla pṛthvīpateḥ
translated: In the forehead of Shiva, the lord of beings, it is awake for the destruction of the small-minded Cupid, and in the arrow of Shiva, it is the cause of the destruction of the pride of rival kings, O King Ballala.🔽Here ends the section on the definition of the Rasas and the Bhävas.

original: bhayānakasya yathā girikuñjeṣu gūḍhānāṃ tavāri varayoṣitām /
analyzed: bhayānakasya yathā giri kuñjeṣu gūḍhānām tava ari vara yoṣitām
translated: Of the Terrible, as in the following verse of mine:🔽The only mark of recognition left of the wives of your enemies, who were concealed in the mountain caves, was the fact that they never looked at the sun.

analyzed: a sūryaṃpaśya tā mātram bhūti cihneṣu aśiṣyata
translated: Of the Disgusting, as in the following verse of mine:

original: bībhatsasya yathā svātmānandaṃ kimapi paramaṃ sādhu saṃbhuñjate ye teṣāmasyāṃ viṣayavitatau jāyate heyabuddhiḥ /
analyzed: bībhatsasya yathā sva ātma ānandam kim api paramam sādhu saṃbhuñjate ye teṣām asyām viṣaya vitatau jāyate heya buddhiḥ
translated: Those who enjoy some supreme bliss of their own, in them is produced a feeling of disgust towards this world of objects.

original: anyeṣāṃ tu prasaratitarāṃ pratyutāsvādanecchā chardiklinne kaphakaluṣite makṣikāṇāmivānne //
analyzed: anyeṣām tu prasaratitarām pratyuta āsvādana icchā chardi klinne kapha kaluṣite makṣikāṇām iva anne
translated: But in others, on the other hand, there arises a desire to taste it, as in the case of flies towards food covered with phlegm and vomit.🔽Of the Marvellous, as in the following verse of mine:

original: adbhutasya yathā ākarṇitottamaguṇānuguṇeti kṛtvā yāmullilekha sucireṇa mano madīyam /
analyzed: adbhutasya yathā ākarṇita uttama guṇa anuguṇā iti kṛtvā yām ullilekha su cireṇa manaḥ madīyam
translated: Having for a long time cherished in my mind the form of her, who is in accordance with the excellent qualities I have heard of,

original: tāmākṛtiṃ visadṛśīmatimātramasyā dāsye 'pi nāsmi viniveśayituṃ vidagdhaḥ //🔽atra sucira madṛṣṭacaranāyikārūpasyānuguṇa śravaṇānurāgiṇo nāyakasya nāyikāprathamadarśane ākarṇitottama guṇānuguṇatayā manasā samullikhitacarī
analyzed: tām ākṛtim visadṛśīm atimātram asyāḥ dāsye na asmi viniveśayitum vidagdhaḥ  atra su cira madṛṣṭa cara nāyikā rūpasya anuguṇa śravaṇa anurāgiṇaḥ nāyakasya nāyikā prathama darśane ākarṇita uttama guṇa anuguṇa tayā manasā samullikhita carī  /
translated: I am not clever enough to place that form, which is so very unlike it, even in the body of a slave.🔽Here, the form of the heroine, which was not seen by the hero for a long time, and which was cherished in his mind by his love for hearing about her qualities,

analyzed: yā nāyikā mūrtiḥ
translated: is the form of the heroine that was imagined by the mind of the hero, who was in love with hearing about her qualities, at the first sight of the heroine.

original: sā samprati sāśrātkṛtanāyikāmūrteratimātraṃ visadṛśī satī dāsītvenāpi niveśayituṃ na śakyata ityuktirābhirūpyanibandhanasya parāṃ kāṣṭhāmāviṣkaroti
analyzed: sā samprati sāśrātkṛta nāyikā mūrteḥ atimātram visadṛśī satī dāsī tvena api niveśayitum na śakyate iti uktiḥ ābhirūpya nibandhanasya parām kāṣṭhām āviṣkaroti
translated: That, being now very dissimilar to the form of the heroine with tears, cannot be made to enter even as a servant. This statement reveals the highest limit of the basis of beauty.

original: śāntasya yathā mā bhaiṣīḥ kula mā vyathasva vinaya kleśo 'stu mā te śruta pradhvaṃsāya yatasva mā khalu mate māhātmya mā mā tyaja /
analyzed: śāntasya yathā mā bhaiṣīḥ kula mā vyathasva vinaya kleśaḥ stu mā te śruta pradhvaṃsāya yatasva mā khalu mate māhātmya mā mā tyaja
translated: As in the case of a peaceful person: Do not be afraid, O family, do not be distressed, O discipline, let there be affliction to you, strive for the destruction of learning, indeed, O mind, do not abandon greatness.

original: yuṣmadrauravasāradāraṇāparānmatvā tṛṇāya prabhūn bhikṣāparyaṭanārjitena kalaye piṇḍena piṇḍasthitim //
analyzed: yuṣmad raurava sāra dāraṇā parān matvā tṛṇāya prabhūn bhikṣā paryaṭana arjitena kalaye piṇḍena piṇḍa sthitim
translated: Considering the lords to be mere grass, other than the destroyers of the essence of your pride, I shall maintain my body with the alms obtained by wandering for alms.

analyzed: ittham rasadhvaniḥ diś mātreṇa udāhṛtaḥ
translated: Thus, Rasa dhvani (suggestion of rasa) has been illustrated by way of mere indication.

original: atha bhāvadhvaniḥbhāvo hi nāma nāyikāvyatirikte devatāgurunṛpaputrādau vyajyamānā ratirvākyārthatvena vyajyamānā nirvedādayo vyabhicāriṇāśca
analyzed: atha bhāva dhvaniḥ bhāvaḥ hi nāma nāyikā vyatirikte devatā guru nṛpa putra ādau vyajyamānā ratiḥ vākya artha tvena vyajyamānā nirveda ādayaḥ vyabhicāriṇāḥ ca
translated: Now, Bhava dhvani (suggestion of bhavas): Bhava (emotion) is the love manifested in a deity, guru, king, prince, etc., other than the heroine, or the sentiments like despair, etc., manifested as the meaning of a sentence, or the transitory emotions.

original: yathā adya svapnamupāgatena yamunātīre mayāvasthitaṃ dṛṣṭastatra ca veṇuvādanipuṇo bālo gavāṃ pālakaḥ /
analyzed: yathā adya svapnam upāgatena yamunā tīre mayā avasthitam dṛṣṭaḥ tatra ca veṇu vāda nipuṇaḥ bālaḥ gavām pālakaḥ
translated: As in: Today, having gone to sleep, I saw on the bank of Yamuna a place where I was staying, and there a boy skilled in playing the flute, a cowherd.

original: taṃ dṛṣṭvā karaṇairananyaviṣayairantarvilīno 'bhavaṃ yāvattāvadahaṃ cirādupacitaiḥ pāpaiḥ prabodhaṃ gataḥ //
analyzed: tam dṛṣṭvā karaṇaiḥ ananya viṣayaiḥ antar vilīnaḥ bhavam yāvat tāvat aham cirāt upacitaiḥ pāpaiḥ prabodham gataḥ
translated: Seeing him, I became absorbed within with faculties turned to no other object, until, after a long time, I was awakened by my accumulated sins.

original: yathā ca saṃsārārtyā vidhuravidhuro brahma yatnādvicinvan nānārūpaṃ jagadidamahaṃ dṛṣṭavāneva pūrvam /
analyzed: yathā ca saṃsāra ārtyāḥ vidhura vidhuraḥ brahma yatnāt vicinvan nānā rūpam jagat idam aham dṛṣṭavān eva pūrvam
translated: And as I, afflicted by the pain of worldly existence, searching for Brahman with effort, have seen this world in various forms before,

original: haste nyaste sati tava guro sāṃprataṃ mastake 'smim brahmaivaitatsakalamabhavanno jagannāpi cāham //
analyzed: haste nyaste sati tava guro sāṃpratam mastake smin brahma eva etat sakalam abhavat naḥ jagat na api ca aham
translated: now, when your hand is placed on my head, O Guru, this is all Brahman, not the world or even I.

original: yathā ca kāṣṭhāprātpiriyaṃ parā khalu parīpākasya bhāgyonnateḥ śrī ballāla nṛpāla/
analyzed: yathā ca parā khalu parīpākasya bhāgya unnateḥ śrī ballāla nṛpāla
translated: And as this is the highest attainment of the fruit of good fortune through long ripening, O glorious King Ballala,

analyzed: yat vayam iṃmau pādau tava upāsmahe
translated: we worship these two feet of yours.

original: yastiṣṭhetpratihāra sīmni bhavato ruddhapraveśaściraṃ kiṃ nāsāvapi colapāṇḍyapṛthvīpālaiḥsamaṃ gaṇyate //
analyzed: yaḥ tiṣṭhet pratihāra sīmni bhavataḥ ruddha praveśaḥ ciram kim nā asau api cola pāṇḍya pṛthvīpālaiḥ samam gaṇyate
translated: If one were to stand at the threshold of your door, his entry long obstructed, would he not be counted along with the Cholas, Pandyas, and Prtthvipalas?

original: itthaṃ putrādiviṣayo vyabhicārirūpaśca bhāvaḥ svayamūhyaḥ /🔽rasābhāso yathā sphuranmukhāmodavivṛddha gandhaṃ /
analyzed: ittham putra ādi viṣayaḥ vyabhicāri rūpaḥ ca bhāvaḥ svayam ūhyaḥ  rasa ābhāsaḥ yathā gandham
translated: Thus, the emotion of love for one's son and so on, and the emotion of contradiction, should be understood by oneself.

analyzed: jighran muhur mīlita rakta netraḥ
translated: An imitation of rasa is like this: Smelling again and again the fragrance enhanced by the sweet scent of the mouth,🔽with closed red eyes,

analyzed: pūrvam priyā cañcu puṭa upayuktam cūta aṅkuram cumbati cañcarīkaḥ
translated: The bee first kisses the mango bud that was enjoyed by the beak of his beloved.

analyzed: ityādi
translated: And so on.

analyzed: atra tiryañc viṣaya tvāt rarasasya ābhāsa tā
translated: Here, the rasa is of the nature of an appearance because it has animals as its object.

analyzed: dhīra udātta tva ādi abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no firmness, loftiness, etc.

original: yadāha uttamaprakṛtirujjvalaveṣaḥ śṛṅgāraḥ iti /🔽bhāvābhāso yathā kvaṇādūdvirephāvalinīlaṅkaṇāṃ prasāryaṃ śākhābhujamāmra vallarī /
analyzed: yat āha uttama prakṛtiḥ ujjvala veṣaḥ śṛṅgāraḥ iti  bhāva ābhāsaḥ yathā vallarī
translated: As it is said: Love is of the nature of the best, with a brilliant dress.🔽The appearance of emotion is like this: The mango creeper, with its mark of blue from the row of humming bees, stretching out its branch-like arms,

analyzed: kṛta upagūhā kalakaṇṭha kūjitaiḥ anāmayam pṛcchati dakṣiṇa anilam
translated: Having made a shelter with the cooing of cuckoos, asks the southern breeze about its welfare.

analyzed: atra sauhārdasya āropita tvāt bhāvaḥ ābhāsī bhavati
translated: Here, emotion becomes an appearance because of the superimposition of affection.

analyzed: bhāva udayaḥ yathā keli talpa gatam aṅghri yāvakam
translated: The rise of emotion is like this: The beloved, with her foot on the bed of love-sports,

analyzed: sūcayati uṣasi cakṣuṣā priye  bhū bhrū tri bhāgam upakalpya bhaṅguram
translated: Indicates with her eyes to her lover in the morning.🔽Having made her eyebrow tremble slightly,

analyzed: gūḍha hāsa madhuram cukopa sā
translated: She pretended to be angry, sweet with hidden laughter.

analyzed: atra lajjā harṣayoḥ udayaḥ
translated: Here, there is the rise of shyness and joy.

original: bhāvasandhiryathā netre jihyakharāruṇe kṣaṇāmatha vyāmīlyamānekṣaṇāṃ hastaṃ vyagragamāganaṃ kṣaṇāmatho dante śayānaṃ kṣaṇam /
analyzed: bhāva sandhiḥ yathā netre kṣaṇām atha vyāmīlyamāna īkṣaṇām hastam kṣaṇām atho dante śayānam kṣaṇam
translated: The union of emotions is like this: Her eyes, red and rough for a moment, then closing, her hand moving restlessly for a moment, then resting on her teeth for a moment,

original: sañcāraṃ viṣamākulaṃ kṣaṇamatha prakrāntalīlaṃ kṣaṇaṃ dhatte totriṣu ṣaṭpadeṣu ca samaṃ dattāvadhāno gajaḥ //🔽atra gajasya madākulasya yadetatkṣaṇamātraṃ netrayoḥ jihyākharā ruṇāyoḥ dharaṇāṃ samanantarameva yaccaitadūvyāmīlanaṃ /
analyzed: sañcāram viṣama ākulam kṣaṇam atha prakrānta līlam kṣaṇam dhatte totriṣu ṣaṭpadeṣu ca samam datta avadhānaḥ gajaḥ  atra gajasya mada ākulasya yat etat kṣaṇa mātram netrayoḥ jihyā kharā ruṇāyoḥ dharaṇām samanantaram eva yat ca etat ūvyāmīlanam
translated: Then, for a moment, his gait is uneven and agitated, and for a moment he begins to play, the elephant, giving equal attention to the goads and the bees.🔽Here, this is the twofold variegated behavior of the elephant, agitated by intoxication: the momentary closing of the eyes, immediately after, on the ground, of the eyes that are red and rough due to the flow of ichor;

original: tathā haste ca yatkṣaṇāmatraṃ vyagro gamāgamaḥ yacca samanantarameva dante śayanaṃ /
analyzed: tathā haste ca yat kṣaṇa amatram vyagraḥ gama āgamaḥ yat ca samanantaram eva dante śayanam
translated: and the momentary coming and going of the trunk, immediately after, lying down on the tusks;

analyzed: sañcāre ca kṣāṇā mātram yā iyam viṣama ākula tā
translated: and that uneven agitation in moving about for a moment;

analyzed: samantaram eva yaḥ ca ayam līlā prakramaḥ
translated: and that beginning of play, immediately after.

original: tadetat vividhaṃ vilakṣaṇaṃ viceṣṭitadvayaṃ udbhavābhibhavadharmitayā kṣaṇaṃ kṣaṇāmāvirbhavat
analyzed: tat etat vividham vilakṣaṇam viceṣṭita dvayam udbhava abhibhava dharmi tayā kṣaṇam kṣaṇām āvirbhavat
translated: This twofold variegated behavior, characterized by arising and being overcome, manifests moment by moment.

original: totriviṣayaṃ roṣaṃ ṣaṭpadaśabdalakṣitaṣaṭpadagītaviṣayaṃ harṣa ca parasparasyādattā
analyzed: totri viṣayam roṣam ṣaṭpada śabda lakṣita ṣaṭpada gīta viṣayam harṣa ca parasparasya ādattā
translated: The anger towards the goads and the joy towards the bees indicated by the word bees, not giving each other an opportunity,

analyzed: vasara tayā samutkṣubhitam abhivyanakti
translated: are agitated and manifest.

original: dvandva vṛttiṣu ca triṣvapi vākyeṣu pratisvaṃ kṣaṇaṃ kṣaṇamityupādānādyathā yathā
analyzed: dvandva vṛttiṣu ca triṣu api vākyeṣu pratisvam kṣaṇam kṣaṇam iti upādānāt yathā yathā
translated: And in all three sentences with dual action, for a moment is used for each, just as

original: samutkṣubhitābdhikallolakatpa latayo totriṇāmuparyupari vinipāta janmāno roṣāveśamahāvegāḥ
analyzed: samutkṣubhita abdhi kallola katpa latayaḥ totriṇām upari upari vinipāta janmānaḥ roṣa āveśa mahā vegāḥ
translated: The great force of the violent passion of anger, born from the repeated falling upon the elephants, like the waves of the agitated ocean,

analyzed: tathā tathā tad abhibhava kṣamāṇām ṣaṭpada gītā karṇa anasukha abhiniveśa vikāsānām madhye
translated: in the midst of those who are capable of overpowering it in such and such a way, who are devoted to the unpleasant sound of the singing of bees, who are in full bloom,

analyzed: prādurbhāvaḥ iti pratyāyyante
translated: it is understood that their appearance is manifested.

original: dhatta iti vartamānanirdeśena prārabdhāparisamātpabhāvādekatarasyāṃ koṭāvaniṣṭheti dyotyate /
analyzed: dhatte iti vartamāna nirdeśena prārabdha a parisamātpa bhāvāt ekatarasyām koṭau aniṣṭhā iti dyotyate
translated: By the use of the present tense in holds, it is indicated that the action has begun but not yet ended, so it is not completed in either alternative.

analyzed: tathā jihvā khara aruṇa tva vyagra gama āgama tva viṣama ākula tva lakṣaṇa dharma yogāt vyālayamāna tva danteśayana tva prakānta līla tva lakṣaṇa dharma yogāt ca anu kṣaṇām ākulībhāvam āpādyamānaiḥ naitra hasta sañcāraiḥ liṅgaiḥ yat etat vodhyate
translated: Similarly, by the indications of the movements of the eyes and hands, which bring about the momentary agitation, characterized by the qualities of the tongue being rough and red, being busy with coming and going, and being uneven and agitated, and characterized by the qualities of lying down on the bed of the tusks, and being engaged in play, it is understood.

original: totriṣuṣaṭpadeṣu ca tulitamavadhānadānaṃ tadapyeka tarasyāṃ koṭā vaniṣṭāmeva vyanakti /
analyzed: ca tulitam avadhāna dānam tat api tarasyām koṭā vaniṣṭām eva vyanakti
translated: The bestowal of attention, which is equal in the elephants and bees, also indicates that it is not completed in either alternative.

analyzed: atas roṣa harṣa bhāvayoḥ ayam sandhiḥ
translated: Therefore, this is the junction of the states of anger and joy.

original: bhāvaśabalatā yathā madhyesakhījanamupahvaravṛttajātaṃ vācā prakāśayati mayyupadeśavṛttyā /
analyzed: bhāva śabalatā yathā madhye sakhī janam upahvara vṛtta jātam vācā prakāśayati mayi upadeśa vṛttyā
translated: The variegatedness of sentiment is as follows: In the midst of her friends, she revealed the secret of her heart to me through the medium of her speech, as if instructing me.

original: sāsūyasapraṇāyasatrapa saprasādaiḥ sā māṃ vilokitavatī caṭulaiḥ kaṭākṣaiḥ //
analyzed: sa asūyasa praṇāya sa trapa sa prasādaiḥ sā mām vilokitavatī caṭulaiḥ kaṭākṣaiḥ
translated: She looked at me with sidelong glances, jealous, affectionate, bashful, and pleased.

analyzed: atra asūyā ādīnām kaṭākṣeṣu samāropāt vācya tā na mantavyā
translated: Here, jealousy and the other emotions should not be considered as expressed, because they are superimposed on the sidelong glances.

analyzed: atas hṛdi evam bhāva śabala tā vyajyate
translated: Therefore, the variegatedness of sentiment is thus conveyed to the heart.

original: bhāvaśāntiryathā tau saṃmukhapracalitau savidhe guruṇāṃ mārgapradānarabhasaskhalitāvadhānau /
analyzed: bhāva śāntiḥ yathā tau saṃmukha pracalitau savidhe guruṇām mārga pradāna rabhasa skhalita avadhānau
translated: The pacification of sentiment is as follows: The two of them, moving towards each other, stumbling with eagerness to give way to the elders,

analyzed: pārśva apasarpaṇām ubhau api bhinna dikkam kṛttvā muhur muhur apāsaratām sa lajjau
translated: having gone to different directions by moving to the sides, went away again and again, both of them bashful.

analyzed: atra mati vibodha
translated: Here, there is the pacification of the two, understanding and awakening.

analyzed: eṣu rasa ādi dhvaniṣu prapañcaḥ nyatas jñeyaḥ
translated: In these cases of suggestion by rasa, etc., the details should be known from other sources.

analyzed: citra kāvya prapañcana pareṇa asmābhiḥ diś mātram udāharaṇaiḥ pradarśitam
translated: The author of the treatise, being devoted to the elaboration of figurative poetry, has shown us only a rough outline with examples, out of extreme brevity.

original: atha saṃlakṣyakrame śabdaśaktimūlo 'laṅkārarūpo vasturūpaśca niyamena bhavati /
analyzed: atha saṃlakṣya krame śabda śakti mūlaḥ laṅkāra rūpaḥ vastu rūpaḥ ca niyamena bhavati
translated: Now, in the case of the sequential, there is invariably the figure of speech or the substance based on the power of the word.

original: tatrālaṅkārarūpo yathā prāpyādharadvayadhurāṃ paricumbatīva līlottaraṃ vilikhatīva nakhatvametya /
analyzed: tatra alaṅkāra rūpaḥ yathā prāpya adhara dvaya dhurām paricumbatī iva līlā uttaram vilikhatī iva nakha tvam etya
translated: Having attained the position of the pair of lips, as if it were kissing playfully, as if it were scratching with the nails,

original: tasyāḥ kaṭākṣavalanaṃ gurusannidhau māmāśrliṣyatīva samavāpya ca bāhubhāvam //
analyzed: tasyāḥ kaṭākṣa valanam guru sannidhau mām āśrliṣyati iva samavāpya ca bāhu bhāvam
translated: the sidelong glance of her, as if embracing me in the presence of her elders, and having attained the state of arms.

original: atrotprekṣālaṅkāreṇa cumbanādikāraṇā bhāve 'pi saṃbhogasukhā vātpilakṣaṇākāryotpattirūpā vibhāvanā vyajyate /
analyzed: atra utprekṣā alaṅkāreṇa cumbana ādi kāraṇā bhāve pi saṃbhoga sukhā vātpi lakṣaṇa akārya utpatti rūpā vibhāvanā vyajyate
translated: Here, even in the absence of the cause of kissing etc., the figure of speech called 'upamā' (simile), in the form of the origination of the effect in the form of the characteristic of the pleasure of enjoyment, is suggested.🔽 Suggestion of fact is as follows:

analyzed: vastu dhvaniḥ yathā dṛṣṭiḥ kātara tām upaiti sahasā tasmin puras vasthite
translated: When he stands before me, my glance becomes timid.

analyzed: narma ālāpini tatra na prativacaḥ jihvā agram ārohati
translated: When he speaks playfully, a reply does not come to the tip of my tongue.

original: saṃsparśaṃ ca na tasya vetyupacitastambhaṃ mamaitadvapuḥ saṃvṛttaḥsakhi saṅgamo 'pi virahaprāyo vidhātāsmi kim //
analyzed: saṃsparśam ca na tasya vā iti upacita stambham mama etat vapuḥ saṃvṛttaḥ sakhi viraha prāyaḥ vidhātāsmi kim
translated: And my body, which does not experience his touch, has become stiff with horripilation. O friend, even the meeting with him is almost like separation. What am I to do?

original: atra vastuni avastutvabhramāt maugdhyalakṣaṇaṃ vastu pratyāyyate /
analyzed: atra vastuni avastu tva bhramāt maugdhya lakṣaṇam vastu pratyāyyate
translated: Here, due to the illusion of non-existence in an existent thing, the fact in the form of shyness is conveyed.

original: athārthaśaktimūlovyañjakor'thaḥ svataḥ saṃbhavī kaviprauḍhoktiniṣpāditaḥ kavirnibaddhavaktṛprauḍhoktiniṣpāditaśceti trirūpaḥ /🔽sa cālaṅkārarūpo vasturūpaśceti pratyekaṃ dvaividhye ṣoḍhā /
analyzed: atha artha śakti mūlaḥ vyañjakaḥ ṛthaḥ svatas saṃbhavī kavi prauḍhā ukti niṣpāditaḥ kaviḥ nibaddha vaktṛ prauḍhā ukti niṣpāditaḥ ca iti trirūpaḥ  sa ca alaṅkāra rūpaḥ vastu rūpaḥ ca iti pratyekam dvaividhye ṣoḍhā
translated: Now, the suggested sense based on the power of the word is of three kinds: (1) naturally possible, produced by the bold statement of the poet; (2) produced by the bold statement of the poet's character as depicted in the poem; and (3) produced by the bold statement of the speaker as depicted in the poem.🔽And each of these is twofold, as being in the form of a fact or in the form of a figure of speech, thus making six varieties.

analyzed: ṣaḍvidhasya ca vyaṅgyaḥ arthaḥ vastu rūpaḥ laṅkāra rūpaḥ ca iti dvādaśaṃbhedaḥ yam
translated: And the suggested sense in these six varieties is twofold, as being in the form of a fact or in the form of a figure of speech, thus making twelve varieties.

original: tathā hi svataḥsaṃbhavinā vastunā vastu svataḥsaṃbhavinā vastunā alaṅkāraḥ /
analyzed: tathā hi svataḥsaṃbhavinā vastunā vastu svataḥsaṃbhavinā vastunā alaṅkāraḥ
translated: For example, (1) a fact by a naturally possible fact; (2) a fact by a naturally possible figure of speech;

analyzed: vastu
translated: (3) a fact by a naturally possible ornament;

analyzed: tena alaṅkāra iti caturdhā
translated: thus, four varieties.

original: tathā kaviprauḍhoktiniṣpāditena vastunā vastu /🔽tenālaṅkāraḥ kaviprauḍhoktiniṣpāditena alaṅkāreṇa vastu tena alaṅkāraḥ ityapi caturdhā /
analyzed: tathā kavi prauḍha ukti niṣpāditena vastunā vastu  tena alaṅkāraḥ kavi prauḍhā ukti niṣpāditena alaṅkāreṇa vastu tena alaṅkāraḥ iti api caturdhā
translated: Similarly, (4) a fact by a fact produced by the bold statement of the poet;🔽(5) a figure of speech by that; (6) a fact by a figure of speech produced by the bold statement of the poet; (7) a figure of speech by that; thus, four varieties.

analyzed: ittham kavi nibaddha vaktṝ prauḍha ukti niṣpādite viṣaye cāturvidhyam anusandheyam
translated: In the same way, the four varieties should be understood in the case of the subject produced by the bold statement of the poet's character as depicted in the poem.

original: atra prapañcaḥ saṃpradāyaprakāśinyāṃ kāvyaprakāśaṭokāyāṃ asmābhiḥ vitatyopa darśita iti tato 'vadhāryaḥ /
analyzed: atra prapañcaḥ saṃpradāya prakāśinyām kāvyaprakāśa ṭokāyām asmābhiḥ vitatya upa darśitaḥ iti tatas
translated: The details of this have been fully shown by us in the Kāvyādarśaṭīkā, which elucidates the traditional interpretation. Therefore, it should be understood from there.

original: iha tu granthagauravabhayāt prastāvānupayogācca na pratanyate /
analyzed: iha tu grantha gaurava bhayāt prastāva anupayogāt ca na pratanyate
translated: But here, out of fear of the bulkiness of the text and because it is not useful for the present context, it is not elaborated.

original: diṅmātrantūdāhliyate tatra svataḥsaṃbhavinā vastunā vastu yathā adyāpi loke na kavirna so 'sti prācāṃ tulāṃ yaḥ prabalo 'dhiroḍhum /
