translated: And in this way, in the present case also, it should be understood that the substance-based dhvani is based on the power of words, due to the relation of indication.

analyzed: atra udāharaṇam sadyas kauśika iti
translated: Here is an example: Sadyah kaushike (immediately, O owl).

analyzed: hariścandracarite nāṭake
translated: In the play Harichandracharita.

original: kauśaikadik ulūkadiśā harṣātmikā te hi prabhāte harṣeṇa kūjanti /
analyzed: kauśa eka diś ulūka diśā harṣa ātmikā te hi prabhāte harṣeṇa kūjanti
translated: The owl-direction is the direction of joy, because they chirp with joy at dawn.

analyzed: yat vā kauśikaḥ indraḥ
translated: Or, the owl is Indra.

analyzed: tasya diś prācī tad vijṛmbhaṇa vaśāt
translated: His direction is the east, due to his expansion.

original: prabhāte hi prācī pratāyate /🔽ākāśaṃ rāṣṭrasamaṃ icchyā tyaktvā valkalasadṛśadhūsarakāntidharaścandraḥ astaśailaṃ yau /
analyzed: prabhāte hi prācī pratāyate  ākāśam rāṣṭra samam icchyā tyaktvā valkala sadṛśa dhūsara kānti dharaḥ candraḥ asta śailam yau
translated: For at dawn, the east expands.🔽The moon, having abandoned the sky, which is like a kingdom, and bearing a luster gray like bark, went to the western mountain.

original: atha tatkāntāpi niśā samullāsibhiralikulaiḥ krandhantaṃ sutamiva kumudākaraṃ sāntvayantī tena saha kṣipraṃ pratasthe /
analyzed: atha tad kāntā api niśā samullāsibhiḥ ali kulaiḥ krandhantam sutam iva kumudākaram sāntvayantī tena saha kṣipram pratasthe
translated: Then the night, his beloved, comforting the cluster of lilies, which was crying like a crying child with the rising flocks of bees, quickly departed with it.

original: sūcanīye tvarthe viśvāmitrakrodhavaśāt icchyā rāṣṭraṃ tyaktvā vārāṇasīṃ prasthitaḥ /
analyzed: sūcanīye tu arthe viśvāmitra krodha vaśāt icchyā rāṣṭram tyaktvā vārāṇasīm prasthitaḥ
translated: In the matter to be suggested, having abandoned his kingdom out of anger towards Viśvāmitra, he set out for Vārāṇasī.

original: tatkāntāpyauśīnarī krandantaṃ rohitāśvaṃ sutaṃ santvayantī tenaiva saha prasthiteti /
analyzed: tat kāntā api auśīnarī krandantam rohitāśvam sutam santvayantī tena eva saha prasthitā iti
translated: His wife Auśīnara, consoling her crying son Rohitāśva, set out with him.

analyzed: iha vastu dhvaniḥ eva iti darśayitum āha atra prabhāta ityādi
translated: To show that here it is only the suggestion of a fact, he says Here, at dawn...

original: nanu dhūsarakāntivalakaleti sutamiveti ca aupamyasambandhasadbhāvāt kathamayaṃ vastudhvanirityata āhavalkalasūtābhyāṃ tviti /
analyzed: nanu dhūsara kānti vala kalā iti sutam iva iti ca aupamya sambandha sadbhāvāt katham ayam vastu dhvaniḥ iti atas āha valkala sūtābhyām tu iti
translated: But how can this be a suggestion of a fact when there is the relation of similarity in the expressions with the beauty of bark-garments and like a son? To this he says But the similarity...

original: sūcanīyārthanairapekṣyeṇa sādṛśyaṃ hi saṃbhavati /🔽prakṛtārthaviṣayatvena tāvanmātreṇa viśramaṇīyaṃ sūcanīyer'the anupayogāt /
analyzed: sūcanīya artha nairapekṣyeṇa sādṛśyam hi saṃbhavati  prakṛta artha viṣaya tvena tāvat mātreṇa viśramaṇīyam sūcanīya irthe anupayogāt
translated: For similarity is possible without regard to the matter to be suggested.🔽It rests merely on that, on the subject matter, because it is of no use in the matter to be suggested.

original: ataḥ prakṛtena saha sūcanīyasya sūcanasambandhācca śabdaśaktimūlo vastudhvanireva /
analyzed: atas prakṛtena saha sūcanīyasya sūcana sambandhāt ca śabda śakti mūlaḥ vastu dhvaniḥ eva
translated: Therefore, it is only a suggestion of a fact based on the power of the word, because of the relation of suggestion between what is suggested and what is primary.

analyzed: ittham sarvatra nāṭaka ādau jñeyam
translated: This should be known in all dramas and such.

original: atha yatra na tulyayogitā nāpi dīpakaṃ tatrāpi nāstyalaṅkārāntaravivikto 'sya viṣaya iti darśayituṃ āhaiheti /
analyzed: atha yatra na tulya yogitā nā api dīpakam tatra api na asti alaṅkāra antara viviktaḥ sya viṣayaḥ iti darśayitum āha aiha iti
translated: Now, even where there is neither equal pairing nor metaphor, in order to show that even there the subject of this [figure] is not devoid of other figures of speech, he says 'ahe' (but).

original: atra viśeṣaṇānāṃ alakākarṣavaktrāsañjanādīnāṃ vallabhaparatayā prathamaṃ pratītiḥ /
analyzed: atra viśeṣaṇānām alaka ākarṣa vaktra āsañjana ādīnām vallabha para tayā prathamam pratītiḥ
translated: Here, the epithets 'alaka-karsin' (brow-raiser), 'vaktra-asanjin' (face-blusher), etc. are first understood as belonging to the beloved.

original: atha itthaṃ vadantyāste lajjā pralīneti sakhīvyavahāke nahi nahīti vallabhasya nihnāvapuraḥsaraṃ kūrpāsakavalyapadeśaḥ kriyate /
analyzed: atha ittham vadantyāḥ te lajjā pralīnā iti sakhī vyavahāke nahi nahi iti vallabhasya nihnāva puraḥsaram kūrpāsa kavalī apadeśaḥ kriyate
translated: Then, when she speaks thus, her shyness disappears, and with the laughter of her friend, the beloved's denial is made under the pretext of her bodice being torn.

original: atra hi na tulyayogitā dīpakaṃ vā ato vivikto 'yaṃ śleṣaviṣaya iti na śaṅkanīyam /
analyzed: atra hi na tulyayogitā dīpakam vā atas viviktaḥ yam śleṣa viṣayaḥ iti na śaṅkanīyam
translated: Here, there is neither equal pairing nor metaphor, so this subject of pun should not be suspected.

analyzed: tatra hetuḥ apahnavuteḥ vidyamāna tvat iti
translated: The reason for this is stated as 'because of the existence of denial'.

analyzed: codayati vastutas iti
translated: He objects: 'in reality'.

original: apahnavo hi vastutaḥsādṛśyārthaṃ pravarttate iha tu sādṛśyaṃ apahnavāya pravṛttimiti nāyamapahnava iti codyam /
analyzed: apahnavaḥ hi vastutas sādṛśya artham pravarttate iha tu sādṛśyam apahnavāya pravṛttim iti na ayam apahnavaḥ iti codyam
translated: For denial proceeds for the sake of similarity in reality, but here similarity proceeds for the sake of denial, so this is not denial, such is the objection.

analyzed: pariharati na ubhayathā api iti  bhūta arthasya prakṛta arthasya
translated: He replies: 'not in either case'.🔽Of the real object, the intended object.

analyzed: prakṛta apahnavaḥ hi apahnuti lakṣaṇam
translated: For denial is the characteristic of the denial of what is intended.

analyzed: sa ca ubhayathā api saṃbhavati iti apahnutiḥ
translated: And that is possible in both ways, so it is Hyperbole.

analyzed: atra saṃgraha ślokam āha sādṛśya vyaktaḥ iti  ādyā a sādṛśya paryavasāyī apahnava rupā  sva prastāve apahnuti prastāve
translated: Here he states a summarizing verse: Similarity is expressed, etc.🔽The first is of the nature of Hyperbole ending in similarity.🔽In the context of Hyperbole.
The second is of the nature of similarity ending in Hyperbole.

analyzed: nigamayati tena alaṅkāra antara iti  śabda sāmyam bhavet śraleṣaḥ viśeṣaṇa viśeṣyayoḥ
translated: He concludes: Therefore, it is a different ornament.🔽There would be Pun if there is verbal similarity between the qualifier and the qualified.

analyzed: prakṛta arthaḥ ced bhedya aṃśe bhinna śabda tā
translated: If one is not the primary meaning, and there is a different word in the differentiated part.

analyzed: śabda artha ubhaya niṣṭhaḥ yam sarva alaṅkāra bādhakaḥ
translated: This is based on both word and meaning, and obstructs all ornaments.

analyzed: pūrva siddhasya ced aṅgam tadā nyāyena bādhyate
translated: But if it is a subsidiary of what is already established, then it is obstructed by reasoning.

original: itthaṃ nyāyanirbhagharatayā anena prapañcito 'pi kāvyaprakāśakṛtā pratipadaṃ khaṇḍito 'yaṃ śleṣo 'laṃṅkāraḥ /
analyzed: ittham anena kāvyaprakāśa kṛtā pratipadam khaṇḍitaḥ yam śleṣaḥ laṃṅkāraḥ
translated: Thus, even though it has been elaborated by the author of the Kāvyādarśa with reasoning free from defects, this Pun ornament is criticized at every step.

analyzed: khaṇḍana yuktayaḥ tu anaucityāt na iha likhyante
translated: But the reasons for the criticism are not written here due to impropriety.

original: saṃpradāyaprakāśinyāṃ tu kāvyaprakāśaṭīkāyāṃ vitatya darśitā iti tat evāvadhāryāḥ /
analyzed: saṃpradāya prakāśinyām tu kāvyaprakāśa ṭīkāyām vitatya darśitāḥ iti tat eva avadhāryāḥ
translated: But they are shown in detail in the commentary on the Kāvyādarśa, which reveals the tradition. They should be understood from there.

analyzed: aprastuta praśaṃsām lilakṣayiṣuḥ viśeṣaṇa vicchritti saṅgati samāpteḥ saṅgati antaram darśayati prastutāt aprastuta ityādi
translated: Desiring to define indirect praise, after the connection of the figure based on adjectives has been completed, he shows another connection, beginning with from the non-primary to the primary.

original: tatra sūtram🔽aprastutāt sā mānyaviśeṣabhāve kāryakāraṇabhāve sārūpye ca prastutapratītā vaprastutapraśaṃsā // //
analyzed: tatra sūtram  aprastutāt sā mānya viśeṣa bhāve kārya kāraṇa bhāve sārūpye ca prastuta pratītā vaprastuta praśaṃsā
translated: There, the aphorism is:🔽When there is a relation of general and particular, cause and effect, or similarity, the indirect praise is the understanding of the primary from the non-primary.

analyzed: sāmānya viśeṣa bhāva ādi saṃbandha avalambena aprastutāt prastuta avagatau aprastuta praśaṃsā
translated: Indirect praise is the understanding of the primary from the non-primary, based on the relation of general and particular, etc.

analyzed: vyācaṣṭe iha aprastutasya iti
translated: He explains: Here, of the non-primary, etc.

analyzed: na hi aprastutam prastuta paraka tva abhāve varṇanīyam
translated: For the non-primary should not be described if it is not subordinate to the primary.

analyzed: a prastuta tvāt
translated: Because it is non-primary.

analyzed: prastuta pratyāyakam ca saṃbandhaḥ
translated: And the relation is that which conveys the primary.

analyzed: tridhā eva sāmānya viśeṣya bhāvaḥ kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ sārūpyam ca iti
translated: There are only three kinds of relations: general and particular, cause and effect, and similarity.

original: tatra sāmānyādviśeṣasya viśeṣādvā sāmānyaviśeṣyabhāvaḥ kāryakāraṇabhāvaḥ sārūpyaṃ ceti /
analyzed: tatra sāmānyāt viśeṣasya viśeṣāt vā sāmānya viśeṣya bhāvaḥ kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ sārūpyam ca iti
translated: Among them, the relation of general and particular is either from the general to the particular or from the particular to the general, and the relation of cause and effect and similarity are also like that.

original: tatra sāmānyadviśesaṣasya viśeṣādvā sāmānyasya pratītiriti dvaividhyam /
analyzed: tatra viśeṣāt vā sāmānyasya pratītiḥ iti dvaividhyam
translated: Among them, the twofold relation is the understanding of the particular from the general or the general from the particular.

analyzed: evam kārya kāraṇa bhāve pi
translated: Similarly, in the case of the relation of cause and effect also.

analyzed: sārūpye tu yadi api na evam
translated: But in similarity, although it is not so,

analyzed: atas pañca prakāraḥ
translated: Therefore, it is of five types.

analyzed: tathā api sādharmya vaidharmyābhyām dvaividhyam bheda antara vat sārūpye pi
translated: Nevertheless, there is a twofold division by similarity and dissimilarity, like another difference, even in similarity.

original: athasarvaiveyaṃ vācyasya saṃbhavena ubhayarūpatayā ceti tridhā /
analyzed: atha sarvā eva iyam vācyasya saṃbhavena ubhaya rūpatayā ca iti tridhā
translated: Now, this is all threefold: by the possibility of the denoted, and by the twofold nature.

original: śliṣṭaśabdaprayoge tu śleṣeṇa na bādhyate prastutasyāvācyatvāt /
analyzed: śliṣṭa śabda prayoge tu śleṣeṇa na bādhyate prastutasya avācya tvāt
translated: But in the use of connected words, it is not contradicted by alliteration, because the presented is not denoted.

analyzed: taṇṇātthi ityādi  tat nāstikima pipatyuḥ pra  kalpitam yat aniyati gṛhiṇyā
translated: As in tannaasthiti etc.🔽That which is imagined by the wife of Necessity,

analyzed: anavarata mana śīlasya kāla pathikasya pātheyam
translated: Which is not, is the provision for the traveler on the path of time, who is constantly restless.

analyzed: vyakhyātam prāk
translated: It has been explained before.

analyzed: sāmānyāt viśeṣa pratītim darśayati atra prahasta ityādi
translated: He shows the understanding of the particular from the general in Here, Prahasta etc.

analyzed: etat tasya iti
translated: This belongs to him.

analyzed: tasya mukhāt etat kiyat
translated: How much of this is from his mouth?

analyzed: vakṣyamāṇasya jāḍya apekṣayā jāḍyam asya alpakam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that compared to the dullness of what is going to be said, his dullness is small.

analyzed: etat iti uktam
translated: This is said.

original: kiṃ tat / kamalinīpatre pāthasaḥ kaṇaṃ muktāmaṇirityāmaṃsteti yat /
analyzed: kim tat kamalinī patre pāthasaḥ kaṇam muktāmaṇiḥ iti āmaṃsta iti yat
translated: What is that? He considered a drop of water on a lotus leaf to be a pearl gem.

analyzed: evam mantā na ati jaḍaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the thinker is not very dull.

original: sa evātijaḍaḥ yastu muktāmaṇidhiyā'dīyamāne tatra pāthaḥkaṇe aṅgulyagrakriyāpravilayini satimama maṇiruḍaḍīya gata iti antaḥśucā na nidrāti
analyzed: saḥ eva ati jaḍaḥ yaḥ tu muktāmaṇi dhiyā ādīyamāne tatra pāthaḥ kaṇe aṅguli agrakriyā pravilayini sati mama maṇiḥ uḍaḍīya gataḥ iti antar śucā na nidrāti
translated: He alone is very dull-witted who, when the water-drop offered there is dissolved by the tip of the finger, and the pearl is taken away, does not sleep due to inner grief, thinking The pearl is taken away.

analyzed: atra viśeṣāt sāmānya pratītim darśayati atra jaḍānām iti
translated: Here he shows the understanding of the general from the particular - Here, of the dull-witted.

analyzed: paśyāmaḥ iti suhṛdā saha nāyikā vṛttānta upavarṇana rūpā nāyaka uktiḥ iyam
translated: We see - this is the statement of the hero, in the form of describing the situation of the heroine along with her friend.

original: kimiyaṃ prapadyata iti paśyāma iti dhiyā saṃlāpaparihārādirūpaṃ sthairyaṃ mayālambitam /
analyzed: kim iyam prapadyate iti paśyāmaḥ iti dhiyā saṃlāpa parihāra ādi rūpam sthairyam mayā ālambitam
translated: We see - with the thought Should she be accepted or not?, I have resorted to steadiness in the form of avoiding conversation.

original: tayā tu ayaṃ khalu śaṭhaḥ māṃ na kimapyālapatītikopa āśritaḥ /
analyzed: tayā tu ayam khalu śaṭhaḥ mām na kim api ālapati iti kopaḥ āśritaḥ
translated: But she has resorted to anger, thinking This rogue does not say anything to me.

original: ityanyonyavailakṣaṇyena darśanacature tasminnavasthāntare mayā vyājena hasitaṃ /
analyzed: iti anyonya vailakṣaṇyena darśana cature tasmin avasthā antare mayā vyājena hasitam
translated: Thus, in him who is skilled in seeing the different states, I laughed with a pretext.

original: tayāpi dhairyataharo bāṣpo muktaḥ /🔽udvāṣpāyāṃ tasyāṃ dhairyameva muktamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tayā api bāṣpaḥ muktaḥ  udvāṣpāyām tasyām dhairyam eva muktam iti arthaḥ
translated: She too released tears with difficulty.🔽In her with tears, steadiness alone was released - this is the meaning.

analyzed: atra kāraṇāt kārya pratītim darśayati atra tathā dhārā adhiruḍhā iti
translated: Here he shows the understanding of the effect from the cause - Here, thus immersed in the stream.

analyzed: māna nivṛtti kārye prastute bāṣpam abhihitam aprastuta tvena vivakṣaṇīyam
translated: When the matter under discussion is the cessation of pride, tears are to be mentioned as something not under discussion.

analyzed: indiḥ iti indu rañjanena iva iti anena mukhasya saundaryam
translated: By Indira and Indurañjana (Indira being a name of Lakshmi, and Indurañjana a kind of collyrium), the beauty of the face is indicated.

original: mṛgīṇāṃ dṛṣṭīrjaḍitaiveti dṛkvāñcalyaṃ /🔽vidrumadalaṃ pramlānāruṇimeveti adharaprabhā /🔽kokilavadhūkaṇṭheṣu kāryaśyaṃ prastutameveti snigdhakaṇṭhatā /
analyzed: mṛgīṇām dṛṣṭīḥ jaḍitā eva iti dṛś vāñcalyam  vidruma dalam pramlāna aruṇimā iva iti adhara prabhā  kokila vadhū kaṇṭheṣu kāryaśyam prastutam evā iti snigdha kaṇṭha tā
translated: By the eyes of the does are paralysed (the charm of the eyes is indicated).🔽By the coral-leaf is faded (the lustre of the lips is indicated).🔽By in the throats of the female cuckoos (the softness of the throat is indicated).

analyzed: barhāḥ sagarhāḥ iva iti ca keśa bhāra vaipulyam pratīyate
translated: By the peacocks are censured (the abundance of the mass of hair is suggested).

analyzed: kāryāt kāraṇa pratīti darśayati atra saṃbhāvyamānaiḥ ityādi
translated: He shows the cognition of the cause from the effect: Here, by those that are possible, that is, by those that are imagined.

analyzed: saṃbhāvyamānaiḥ utprekṣyamāṇaiḥ
translated: By those that are possible, that is, by those that are imagined.

analyzed: atra ati vyātpim āśāṅkate nanu kāryāt ityādi
translated: Here he suspects over-extension: But from the effect, etc.

original: yena lambālaka itiatra lambālakatvādinā kāryeṇa gajāsuravadharūpakāraṇapratītiḥ /
analyzed: yena lambālakaḥ iti atra lambālaka tva ādinā kāryeṇa gaja asura vadha rūpa kāraṇa pratītiḥ
translated: By which (the effect), the hanging tresses, etc., the cognition of the cause in the form of the slaying of the demon Gajāsura (is produced).

analyzed: cakra abhighāta iti atra ratasya āliṅgana vandhya tva cumbana mātra śeṣa tva rūpa kārya bhedāt rāhuśiraḥ chedaḥ kāraṇam
translated: By the stroke of the discus, here, by the difference in the effect in the form of the fruitlessness of the embrace and the remaining only of the kissing, the cause is the cutting off of Rahu's head.

analyzed: atra ativyātpim darśayati atra hi ityādi
translated: Here he shows over-extension: For here, etc.

analyzed: pariharati na eṣa doṣaḥ iti
translated: He replies: This is not a fault.

original: dvayorapi prastutatve kāraṇāpekṣayā kāryopavarṇanasya sacamatkāratve taddvārā kāraṇapratyāyanaṃ paryāyoktaviṣayaḥ /
analyzed: dvayoḥ api prastuta tve kāraṇa apekṣayā kārya upavarṇanasya sa camatkāra tve tad dvārā kāraṇa pratyāyanam paryāyokta viṣayaḥ
translated: When both are presented, the description of the effect in relation to the cause, which is delightful, and the understanding of the cause through that, is the subject of Paryayokta.

analyzed: kāryasya a prastuta tve tu aprastuta praśaṃsāyāḥ iti vibhāgaḥ
translated: But when the effect is not presented, it is Prastutapraśaṃsā. This is the division.

analyzed: vibhakta viṣaya tayā nigamayati evam yatra ityādi  tādṛśam evam
translated: He concludes by distinguishing the subjects: Thus, where...🔽Such is this.

analyzed: prakṛtam eva
translated: The present itself.

analyzed: āgūrayati sāmarthyāt ānayati
translated: It brings, by implication.

original: itthaṃ ca sati prakṛtasyaca sataur'thasya svopaskārāya prakṛtānatarāgūraṇe paryāyoktameveci prathanāya punarāhatataśca anayetyādi /
analyzed: ittham ca sati prakṛtasya ca sataurthasya sva upaskārāya prakṛta anatara āgūraṇe paryāya uktam eva i ci prathanāya punar āha tatas ca anayā ityādi
translated: And in this case, when the present meaning is to be brought in for one's own assistance in the present, it is Paryayokta. To make it clear again, he says: And therefore, by this...

analyzed: rājan iti
translated: O King!

analyzed: kubjā śuka bhojana niyuktā
translated: The hunchback is appointed to feed the parrot.

analyzed: kumāra iti saṃbodhanam
translated: The address is O prince.

analyzed: tad sacivāḥ sajagdhyā adhikāriṇaḥ
translated: The ministers are the officials with proper authority.

analyzed: rāja śukaḥ śreṣṭha śukaḥ
translated: The royal parrot is the best parrot.

original: atra rājaśukavṛttasyāpi nāyakapratāpāṅgatayā prakṛtatvāt paryāyoktameva boddhavyam /
analyzed: atra rāja śuka vṛttasya api nāyaka pratāpa aṅga tayā prakṛta tvāt paryāya uktam eva boddhavyam
translated: Here, the conduct of the royal parrot should also be understood as Paryayokta, because it is present as an attribute of the hero's prowess.

analyzed: anyeṣām hṛdayam āha anye tu iti
translated: Others say...

analyzed: kāraṇa rūpasya
translated: Of the cause, in the form of the fleeing of the enemy, the destroyer of the mark.

The condensed meaning is the extracted meaning without regard to the specific details.

analyzed: apratītaḥ pratyāyyate ced pratyāyya pratyayaka bhāvaḥ tadā anumānam
translated: If what is not understood is made to be understood, then if there is the relation of the one to be convinced and the convincer, that is inference.

original: pratītaḥsamarthyate cet samarthyasamarthakabhāvaḥ tadā padārthasya tvatalādiśiraskatayā hetutvenopādāne na kaścidalaṅkāraḥ /
analyzed: pratītaḥ samarthyate ced samarthya samarthaka bhāvaḥ tadā padārthasya tu a tala ādi śiraska tayā hetu tvena upādāne na kaścid alaṅkāraḥ

analyzed: yathā nāga indra hastāḥ ityādau

original: karkaśatvāt ūrvorupamānabāhyā iti hetumadbhāvasya laukikatvāt /🔽yadā tvatalādyasaṃsparśenopāttasya padārthasya hetutvaṃ tadā mṛgaśca darbhāṅkuretyādau padārthanimandhanamekaṃ kāvyaliṅgam /

translated: Because the state of having a reason, like 'because of the roughness of the thighs', is common in everyday speech.🔽But when the object, not connected with 'tataḥ' (therefore) or 'tala' (because), is used as the reason, then in examples like 'Mṛgaśca darbhāṅkure' etc., the object-based figure of speech is one.

analyzed: yadā punar vākya arthaḥ hetu tva pratipādaka yat śrabda ādi prayogam antareṇa hetu tvena upādīyate
translated: When again the meaning of a sentence is used as the reason without the use of words like 'yaḥ' (who) etc. which express the reason,

analyzed: tadā vākya artha nibandhanam anyat kāvya liṅgam
translated: then it is another figure of speech based on the meaning of a sentence.

original: yadā tāṭasthyenopāttasya vākyasya arthaparyālocanayā hetutvaṃ tadārtāntaranyāsaḥ /

analyzed: samarthya vākya arthasya anayā kriyayā sāpekṣa tvena tāṭasthya abhāvāt

analyzed: artha antara nyāsaḥ tu sāmānya viśeṣa bhāvaḥ eva bhavati

analyzed: tathātve eva tāṭasthya saṃbhavāt

analyzed: anumānam tu sādhyāya sādhanasya upavarṇanā

analyzed: padārthāt vā atha vākya arthāt nirdeśe sati hetutaḥ

analyzed: saṅgati antarāya āha evam tarka iti

analyzed: etad viparyayaḥ pi na asti iti āha abhūta bhāvi iva iti
translated: And this opposite is also not so, he says Nor the opposite.

original: yañcātra pratyakṣatvaṃ tadapyanyathā adhyavasīyate ityāhana cāpīti /
analyzed: yat ca atra pratyakṣa tvam tat api anyathā adhyavasīyate iti āha na ca api iti
translated: And that manifestation here is also determined otherwise, he says Nor is it.

analyzed: viparyayaḥ pi na asti iti āha apratyakṣam vā iti
translated: And the opposite is also not so, he says Nor non-manifestation.

original: nanubhūtabhāvinoḥ apratyakṣayoḥ pratyakṣāyamāṇatvam anyathādhyavasāya ityata āhana hi pratyakṣatvamiti /
analyzed: nanu bhūta bhāvinoḥ apratyakṣayoḥ pratyakṣāyamāṇa tvam anyathā adhyavasāyaḥ iti atas āha na hi pratyakṣa tvam iti
translated: But it may be argued that the past and future, which are not perceptible, appear as if they were perceptible, and so there is a determination of what is otherwise. To this he says: For perception is not merely a property of the object.

analyzed: yadi pratyakṣa tvam kevala valaḥ tu dharmaḥ tadā bhūta bhāvinoḥ apratyakṣa tā
translated: If perception were merely a property of the object, then the past and future would not be perceptible.

analyzed: vartamānasya tu pratyakṣa tvam iti bhavet vyavasthā
translated: But the present would be perceptible. Thus there would be a distinction.

analyzed: na hi pratyakṣa tvam kevala vastu dharmaḥ
translated: For perception is not merely a property of the object.

analyzed: kim tarhi pratipattṛ apekṣayā eva pratyakṣasya iti vastu dharma tā
translated: What then? Perception is a property of the object only in relation to the cognizer.

original: na hi pratipattāramanapekṣya vastuni pratyakṣatā nāma kācit /
analyzed: na hi pratipattāram an apekṣya vastuni pratyakṣa tā nāma kācid
translated: For there is no such thing as perceptibility in an object without regard to the cognizer.

analyzed: atra prāmāṇika saṃvādāya āha yat cat āhuḥ ityādi
translated: Here, to show agreement with the authoritative, he says and they say and so on.

analyzed: yaḥ hi arthaḥ sva grahaka pratipattuḥ jñāna prakāśam sva anvaya vyatirekau anukārayati
translated: For that object which causes the cognition of its own apprehender to conform to its own positive and negative concomitance,

analyzed: svayam asti ced jñāna pratibhāsaḥ sti
translated: if the appearance in cognition exists, it exists.

analyzed: na asti ced na asti iti vyavasthāpayati
translated: If it does not exist, it is established as non-existent.

analyzed: sa pratyakṣaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning of perception.

original: ataḥ pratyakṣatvaṃ na kevalaṃ vastudharmaḥ pratipattustu sāmagrī tatra upayujyata ityāhakevralamiti /🔽asāmagrīke pratipattari na vastu pratyakṣībhavatītyetāvadvaktuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: atas pratyakṣa tvam na kevalam vastu dharmaḥ pratipattuḥ tu sāmagrī tatra upayujyate iti āha kevralam iti  asāmagrīke pratipattari na vastu pratyakṣībhavati iti etāvat vaktum śakyate
translated: Therefore, the fact of being perceptible is not merely a property of the object; rather, the assemblage of conditions is useful for the cognizer. Thus he says only.🔽It can be said that when the cognizer lacks the assemblage of conditions, the object does not become perceptible.

analyzed: na tu pekṣā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that it does not depend on the cognizer.

analyzed: tām sāmagrīm vivecayati sā ca iti
translated: He analyzes that assemblage of conditions, saying and that.

original: lokayātrāyāṃ laukikārthaṃ pratyakṣīkaraṇe deśakālādivyavadhānādatīndriyer'the yoginām aikāgṣātmakabhāvanārūpā /
analyzed: lokayātrāyām laukika artham pratyakṣīkaraṇe deśa kāla ādi vyavadhānāt atīndriya irthe yoginām aikāgṣa ātmaka bhāvanā rūpā
translated: In the course of worldly life, in the perception of worldly objects, for yogis in regard to imperceptible objects due to spatial and temporal obstructions, it is in the form of meditation consisting of single-pointed concentration.

analyzed: sākṣātkaraṇa sāmagrī yojayati sā ca iti
translated: The assemblage of conditions for direct perception he connects with the wonderful nature present in the subject matter of poetry, saying and that.

original: atyadbhutāni hi vastūni ādarapratyayena hṛdi sandhāryamāṇāni tathā bhāvanāṃ prayojayanti /
analyzed: ati adbhutāni hi vastūni ādara pratyayena hṛdi sandhāryamāṇāni tathā bhāvanām prayojayanti
translated: For wonderful objects, when retained in the heart with the notion of respect, they induce such meditation.

original: itthaṃ ca satilikayātrāyāṃ vartamānārthasākṣātkaraṇasāmagrī cakṣurādiryogināṃ kāvyatattvavidāṃ cātītānāgatārthasākṣātkaraṇabhāvanā /
analyzed: ittham ca sa tilika yātrāyām vartamāna artha sākṣātkaraṇa sāmagrī cakṣuḥ ādiḥ yoginām kāvya tattva vidām ca atīta anāgata artha sākṣātkaraṇa bhāvanā
translated: And in this case, the assemblage of conditions for the direct perception of present objects in the course of worldly life is the eye etc. for yogis, and the meditation for the direct perception of past and future objects for those who know the truth of poetry.

original: ato yogivat kāvyatattvavidāmatītārthasākṣātkāro nānyathādhyavasāya iti nātiśayoktiḥ śaṅkyā /
analyzed: atas yogi vat kāvya tattva vidām atīta artha sākṣātkāraḥ na anyathā adhyavasāyaḥ iti na atiśayoktiḥ śaṅkyā
translated: Therefore, like yogis, for those who know the truth of poetry, the direct perception of past objects is not a case of superimposition.

original: nanu pratyakṣatayaiva pratīyante bhūtabhāvina iti pratīyamānotprekṣā kiṃ na syādityata āhanāpi bhūtabhāvināmiti /
analyzed: nanu pratyakṣa tayā eva pratīyante bhūta bhāvinaḥ iti pratīyamāna utprekṣā kim na syāt iti atas āha nā api bhūta bhāvinām iti
translated: But it may be argued that since past and future objects are perceived as if they were present, why should it not be a case of perceived imagination? To this he says: Nor is it a case of past and future objects.

analyzed: tatra hetuḥ tasya abhimāna iti
translated: The reason for this is stated: because it is in the form of an assumption.

analyzed: abhimānaḥ saṃbhāvanā tad rūpasya adhyavasāyaḥ iti utprekṣāyāḥ lakṣaṇam
translated: The definition of imagination is: the determination in the form of an assumption.

analyzed: na hi atra apratyakṣam pratyakṣa tayā saṃbhāvyate
translated: Here, what is not directly perceived is not imagined to be directly perceived.

analyzed: kim tarhi pratyakṣam dṛśyate
translated: What then? The directly perceived is seen.

analyzed: atas na utprekṣā  anutprekṣā tve gamaka antaram āha na api vastu iti
translated: Therefore, it is not imagination.🔽To show another reason for not being imagination, he says: Nor is it a case of a real object.

original: padārthagato hi ivārthaḥ upamāyāḥ prayojako notprekṣātve gamakāntaramāhanāpi vastviti /
analyzed: padārtha gataḥ hi iva arthaḥ upamāyāḥ prayojakaḥ na utprekṣā tve gamaka antaram āha na api vastu iti
translated: The meaning of 'as if' in the meaning of a word is the cause of simile, not of imagination.

original: padārthagato hi ivārthaḥ upamāyāḥ prayojako notprekṣāyāḥ /
analyzed: padārtha gataḥ hi iva arthaḥ upamāyāḥ prayojakaḥ na utprekṣāyāḥ
translated: The meaning of 'as if' in the meaning of a word is the cause of simile, not of imagination.

analyzed: tatra hetuḥ tasyāḥ abhimāna iti
translated: The reason for this is stated: because it is in the form of an assumption.

analyzed: utprekṣā hi abhimāna rūpā pratipattṝ dharmaḥ
translated: For imagination is a form of assumption, a property of the perceiver.

original: tasmādabhimānagocara eva ivārthaṃ utprekṣāprayojaka iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt abhimāna gocaraḥ eva iva artham utprekṣā prayojakaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, the object of conceit itself is the cause of imagination, this is the idea.

analyzed: atra saṃvādāya āha yat āhuḥ ityādi
translated: Here, for confirmation, he says what they say, etc.

analyzed: sukha ādi vat jñāna dharme bhimāne dhyavasāya uktiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in the case of the property of knowledge, like pleasure, etc., it is said to be determination in conceit.

original: nanu pratipattṝdharmo 'dhyavasāyastarhi prayoktuḥ kaveḥ na syādityata āhakāvyaviṣaye ceti /
analyzed: nanu pratipattṛ dharmaḥ dhyavasāyaḥ tarhi prayoktuḥ kaveḥ na syāt iti atas āha kāvya viṣaye ca iti
translated: But if determination is the property of the cognizer, then it would not belong to the author, the poet. To this he says in the domain of poetry, etc.

analyzed: kaviḥ api khalu kāvye sahṛdayaḥ eva
translated: The poet too, indeed, is a connoisseur in poetry.

analyzed: atas na iyam utprekṣā  nanu adbhuta darśanāt pratyakṣa tvam iha iti kāvya liṅgam iti atas āha na api atyadbhuta iti
translated: Therefore, this is not imagination.🔽But it is a poetic convention here because of the perception of the marvelous. To this he says not even in the case of the marvelous, etc.🔽For the perception of a highly marvelous object is the cause of seeming perception.

analyzed: ati adbhuta padārtha sākṣātkāraḥ hi pratyakṣāyamāṇa tve hetuḥ  akāvya liṅga tve hetum āha liṅga liṅgī iti
translated: He gives the reason for not being a poetic convention in the case of the mark and the marked, etc.

analyzed: hetu tve sati api liṅga liṅgi bhāvena nā iha pratītiḥ
translated: Even though it is a cause, there is no cognition here as the mark and the marked.

analyzed: tathātve pārokṣyam prasajet iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that if it were so, then it would lead to obscurity.

analyzed: katham tarhi pratītiḥ iti atas āha yogi vat iti
translated: How then is there cognition? To this he says like a yogi.

analyzed: nanu ati adbhuta tva hetukā sa camatkāra pratītiḥ iha puras sphurati iva
translated: But the cognition accompanied by wonder, caused by the marvelous, appears vividly here.

analyzed: tyadbhuta tva hetukaḥ rasavat alaṅkāraḥ eva iti atas āha na api ayam iti
translated: Therefore, it is only the figure of speech called rasa, which is the cause of the highest wonder. Hence he says: This is not so.

analyzed: tatra hetuḥ rati ādi iti
translated: The reason for that is: because of the emotions etc.

analyzed: paripāṭyā api sa camatkāra pratīteḥ puras sphuraṇā sādhāraṇī
translated: Even in succession, the common manifestation is of the delightful cognition.

analyzed: atha api na bhāvika rasavatoḥ abhedaḥ
translated: Even so, there is no non-difference between the real rasa and the rasa-like.

original: kutaḥ / ratihāsādicittavṛttīnāṃ tadanurañjitatvena vibhāvānubhāvavyabhicāriṇāṃ ca🔽yadā paramādvaitajñānivat mamaiva śatrorevetyādiviśeṣaparihārāt sādhāraṇyena hṛdayasaṃvādinī
analyzed: kutas rati hāsa ādi cittavṛttīnām tad anurañjita tvena vibhāva anubhāva vyabhicāriṇām ca  yadā parama advaita jñāni vat mama eva śatroḥ eva ityādi viśeṣa parihārāt sādhāraṇyena hṛdaya saṃvādinī
translated: Why? Because the mental modifications such as love etc. are tinged by that, and the excitants, ensuents and variants

original: pratītiḥ tadaiva rasavato bhāvaḥ /🔽vibhānādīn rasavatprastutau vivecayiṣyena hṛdayasaṃvādinī pratītiḥ tadaiva rasavato bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: pratītiḥ tadā eva rasavataḥ bhāvaḥ
translated: When there is cognition that accords with the heart by being common, by avoiding distinctions such as mine, of the enemy etc., like the knowledge of the highest non-dualism, then alone there is the state of the rasa-like.

analyzed: vibhāva ādīn rasavat prastutau vivecayiṣyāmaḥ
translated: We will distinguish the excitants etc. from the presented rasa-like.

original: iha tubhūtabhāvināṃ pratītirna sādhāraṇyena apitu pratipattuḥ tāṭsthyena /
analyzed: iha tu bhūta bhāvinām pratītiḥ na sādhāraṇyena apitu pratipattuḥ tāṭsthyena
translated: Here, the cognition of the past and future is not common, but rather of the perceiver in a neutral way.

analyzed: sphuṭa tayā tādasthyam hi bhedaḥ
translated: The neutrality in a clear way is the difference.

original: yathā sāṅkhyādisiddhānāṃ bhede na sarvaṃ jānatāṃ pratītiḥ /
analyzed: yathā sāṅkhya ādi siddhānām bhede na sarvam jānatām pratītiḥ
translated: Just as the cognition of those who know everything is not in the difference of the accomplishments of the Sankhya etc.

analyzed: nanu tāṭasthyena pratītau atīta ādi sphuṭa tvam hetuḥ
translated: But when the object is cognized as remote, the vividness of the past etc. is the reason.

analyzed: sphuṭa pratītiḥ ca pramukhe niṣpattau tu sādhāraṇya pratītiḥ eva
translated: And vivid cognition is indeed the cause of the arising of the remote, which is the cognition of commonality in the case of accomplishment in front.

analyzed: atas katham bhāvikam iti atas āha sphuṭa pratipatti iti
translated: Therefore, how can it be based on reality? To this he says vivid cognition.

analyzed: sphuṭa pratipatti nimittaka sphuṭa pratīti utthāpita bhāvika hetukaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is based on the remote cause that arises from the vivid cognition that is the cause of vivid cognition.

original: munirjayatityādau hi kumbhasambhavādivṛttamādau tāṭasthyena atītādirūpatayā pratīyate tadaiva bhāvikasiddhiḥ /
analyzed: muniḥ jayati tyādau hi kumbha sambhava ādi vṛttam ādau tāṭasthyena atīta ādi rūpa tayā pratīyate tadā eva bhāvika siddhiḥ
translated: For in the case of the sage is victorious, etc., the occurrence of Kumbhasambhava, etc. is first cognized as past etc. in the form of remoteness, and at that very time there is the establishment of the remote.

original: athoktarakālaṃ pratipattṝpratīteḥ tādrūpyāpattyā vibhāvādīnāṃ sādhāraṇye rasavān bhāvikahetukaḥsyāt /
analyzed: atha uktara kālam pratipattṝ pratīteḥ tādrūpya āpattyā vibhāva ādīnām sādhāraṇye rasavān bhāvika hetukaḥ syāt
translated: Then, after the cognition of the audience, by the attainment of that form, the commonality of the vibhāvas etc. would be rasaful and based on the remote cause.

analyzed: na ca etāvatā bhāvika apalāpaḥ śakyate iti yāvat
translated: And it is not possible to deny the remote by this much.

analyzed: nanu iha sundara vastu svabhāvaḥ ced na varṇyeta tatas tad apratyakṣāyamāṇa tā
translated: But if the nature of a beautiful object is not described here, then it would not be perceived.

analyzed: atas svabhāva uktiḥ iti atas āha na api iyam iti
translated: Therefore, it is a statement of nature. To this he says nor is this.

analyzed: tatra hetuḥ tasyām laukikā iti
translated: The reason there is in that worldly usage.

original: svabhāvokterhi laukikānāmeva vastūnāṃ yaḥsūkṣmo dharmaḥ prekṣāvatpratibhaika samadhigamyastasya varṇane hṛdayasaṃvādaḥsādhāraṇyena /
analyzed: svabhāva ukteḥ hi laukikānām eva vastūnām yaḥ sūkṣmaḥ dharmaḥ prekṣāvat pratibhā eka samadhigamyaḥ tasya varṇane hṛdaya saṃvādaḥ sādhāraṇyena
translated: For in natural description, the subtle property of only worldly things, which is to be understood by the intellect alone, is described, and there is agreement with the heart in a general way.

analyzed: iha punar ati adbhuta tvena alaukikānām vastūnām pratītiḥ taṭastha tayā
translated: But here, the understanding of non-worldly things is by way of being set apart, because of their being extremely wonderful.

analyzed: atas hṛdaya saṃvāda atiriktānām aṃsānām vailakṣaṇyam
translated: Therefore, the difference of the parts is from agreement with the heart, and from other qualities.
But in the commonness of the understanding of worldly things, there is natural description.

analyzed: alaukika vastu pratīti sphuṭa tve tu bhāvikam iti vyavasthā
translated: But in the clearness of the understanding of non-worldly things, there is the real. This is the rule.

original: yadi laukikavastupratīteḥspuṭatvaṃ tadā kiṃ syādityata āhakvacittviti /
analyzed: yadi laukika vastu pratīteḥ spuṭa tvam tadā kim syāt iti atas āha kvacid tu iti
translated: If there is clearness in the understanding of worldly things, then what would happen? To this he says: But in some cases, etc.
Natural description is by the power of worldly things.

analyzed: sphuṭa tva pratīti balāt bhāvika mataḥ saṅkaraḥ
translated: The real is by the power of the clear understanding. Therefore, there is a mixture.

original: hṛdayasaṃvādasādhāraṇyāt svābhāvoktirasavatoryo 'yamabhedaḥ prasaṅgātpratītastatra vivecayatina ca hṛdayasaṃvādeti /
analyzed: hṛdaya saṃvāda sādhāraṇyāt sva abhāva ukti rasavatoḥ yaḥ yama bhedaḥ prasaṅgāt pratītaḥ tatra vivecayati na ca hṛdaya saṃvāda iti
translated: Because of the commonness of agreement with the heart, this non-difference of the natural description and the real, which has been understood by implication, he distinguishes there: And in agreement with the heart, etc.

original: svabhāvoktau rasavati ca yadyapi sādhāraṇyena hṛdayasaṃvādaḥsacetasāṃ /
analyzed: svabhāva uktau rasavati ca yadi api sādhāraṇyena hṛdaya saṃvādaḥ sa cetasām
translated: Even though in natural description and in the real, there is agreement with the heart of the intelligent in a general way,

analyzed: tathā api na anayoḥ abhedaḥ
translated: Even so, there is no non-difference between these two.

analyzed: tatra hetuḥ vastu svabhāva iti
translated: The reason for that is stated as 'in the nature of the thing'.

original: satyapi sādhāraṇye vastusvabhāvasya saṃvādaḥ svabhāvoktau rasavati tu cittavṛtteḥ /
analyzed: sati api sādhāraṇye vastu svabhāvasya saṃvādaḥ svabhāva uktau rasavati tu citta vṛtteḥ
translated: Even when there is commonality, there is agreement with the nature of the thing in the statement of nature, but when there is rasa, there is the activity of the mind.

analyzed: vastu svabhāva citta vṛtti rūpa tvāt anayoḥ saṃpāte tu saṅkaraḥ iti āha aubhaya saṃvāda iti
translated: Because these two are of the nature of the thing and the activity of the mind, when they come together there is a mixture. Thus he says 'in the agreement of both'.

analyzed: samāveśaḥ saṅkaraḥ  samāveśa ghaṭane liṅgam āha yatra vastugata iti
translated: The mixture is the combination.🔽He states the reason for the combination as 'where there is the quality of the thing'.

analyzed: yatra citta vṛtti saṃvādavati viṣaye vastugata sūkṣma dharma varṇanā syāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in an object that has the agreement of the activity of the mind, there should be a description of the subtle qualities of the thing.

analyzed: anyatra tu iti
translated: 'But elsewhere',

analyzed: sūkṣma vastu dharma varṇanā virahiṇi cittavṛtti saṃvāda mātra śālini viṣaye rasavān eva
translated: in an object that lacks the description of the subtle qualities of a thing but has only the agreement of the activity of the mind, there is only rasa.

original: nanu vyastasambandharahitasandarbhasamarpitatvamiha lakṣaṇaṃ tathātve ca prasādākhyo guṇa evetyata āhanāpyayaṃ śabdetyādi /
analyzed: nanu vyasta sambandha rahita sandarbha samarpita tvam iha lakṣaṇam tathātve ca prasāda ākhyaḥ guṇaḥ eva iti atas āhana api ayam śabda ityādi
translated: But isn't the definition here that it is presented by a context free from disconnected relations, and if that were so, it would be only the quality called clarity? To that he says 'this is not the word' and so on.

original: iha yadyapi jhaṭityarthasamarpaṇaṃ śabdānākulatvahetakaḥ athāpi nāyaṃ prasādaḥ /
analyzed: iha yadi api jhaṭiti artha samarpaṇam śabda an ākula tva hetakaḥ atha api na ayam prasādaḥ
translated: Here, although the quick presentation of meaning is the cause of the word being unconfused, this is not clarity.

original: tatra hetuḥ tasya hi sphuṭā sphuṭetyādi /
analyzed: tatra hetuḥ tasya hi sphuṭā sphuṭā ityādi
translated: The reason for that is stated as 'that has the clear and clear' and so on.

analyzed: sphuṭaḥ stu vākya arthaḥ asphuṭaḥ vā
translated: Let the meaning of the sentence be clear or not clear.
The form of prasāda is the immediate presentation of both.

original: yadāha śuṣkendhanāgnivat svacchrajalavat sahasaiva yat /🔽vyāpnotyanyat prasādo 'sau sarvatra vihitasthitiḥ //
analyzed: yat āha śuṣka indhana agni vat svacchra jala vat sahasā eva yat  vyāpnoti anyat sau sarvatra vihita sthitiḥ
translated: As it is said: That which pervades others like a fire in dry fuel, like clear water, suddenly,

analyzed: iti
translated: That prasāda is present everywhere.

original: atra śuṣkendhanāgnivadityasphuṭaṃ vākyārthaṃ prasyupamoktiḥ svacchrajalavaditi sphuṭaṃ prati /
analyzed: atra śuṣka indhana agni vat iti asphuṭam vākya artham prasyupamā uktiḥ svacchra jala vat iti sphuṭam prati
translated: Here, the simile of a fire in dry fuel is for the unclear meaning of the sentence, and the simile of clear water is for the clear [meaning].

original: ataḥsarvatra vihita sthititvena jhaṭiti samarpaṇaṃ rūpaṃ prasādasya /
analyzed: atas sarvatra vihita sthiti tvena jhaṭiti samarpaṇam rūpam prasādasya
translated: Therefore, the form of prasāda is the immediate presentation by being present everywhere.

original: asya tu prasāde jhaṭiti samarpitasya sphuṭatvena pratītau satyāṃ samanantaraṃ svarūpapratilambhaḥ /
analyzed: asya tu prasāde jhaṭiti samarpitasya sphuṭa tvena pratītau satyām samanantaram sva rūpa pratilambhaḥ
translated: But when this prasāda, which is immediately presented, is perceived as clear, its own nature is immediately attained.

original: svarūpaṃ hi asyaśrotari kavigatabhāvapratibimbanaṃ paunaḥpunyena cetasi viniveśasvabhāvabhāvanātmakaṃ vā /🔽tathāvidhasya tu pratibambanaṃ sphuṭapratītyuttarakālameva /

analyzed: tau eva aviṣaya pravṛttau ābhāsau
translated: Those two, when engaged in an improper object, are Ābhāsas.

analyzed: prayāsyat avasthā tu praśamaḥ
translated: But the state of being about to cease is Praśama.

original: eṣāṃ caturṇāmupanibandhe paripāṭyā rasavān preyaḥ ūrjasvi samāhitamiti alaṅkārā iti sūtrārthaḥ /

translated: And the sense of the aphorism is that in the composition of these four, Rasavat, Preyas, Ūrjasvi, and Samāhita are ornaments in order.

analyzed: sa saṅgatikam vyācaṣṭe udātte mahāpuruṣa ityādinā
translated: He explains with the connection, beginning with in the great man, the exalted.

analyzed: tad alaṅkārāṇām cittavṛtti vicchitti ātmanām alaṅkārāṇām iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they are ornaments in the form of the modification of mental states of those ornaments.

analyzed: atas eva iti

analyzed: cittavṛtti ātmānaḥ atas samāna yogakṣema tayā yugapad eka sūtra kroḍīkāreṇa lakṣitāḥ
translated: And since all four are of the nature of mental modifications, they are described together in one aphorism, as sharing the same fate.

analyzed: rasa svarūpam vivecayati tatra vibhāvā iti
translated: In order to examine the nature of rasa, it is said: There, the excitants, etc.

original: ratihāsaśokādīnāṃ vāsanātmanāṃ sthāyibhāvānāṃ yāni loke kāryakāraṇasahakārīṇi tāni
analyzed: rati hāsa śoka ādīnām vāsanā ātmanām sthāyi bhāvānām yāni loke kārya kāraṇa sahakārīṇi tāni

original: kāvye sandṛbdhāni nāṭye cābhinītāni guṇālaṅkāramahimnā caturvidhābhinayamahimnā ca
analyzed: kāvye sandṛbdhāni nāṭye ca abhinītāni guṇa alaṅkāra mahimnā caturvidha abhinaya mahimnā ca

translated: They are called excitants, ensuants, and variants because they manifest, intensify, and directly engage the emotions.

original: taiḥ prakāśito vyañcito ratyādiḥ sāmājikacittavṛttiviśeṣaḥ śṛṅgārādiko rasa iti dik /

translated: The emotion like love, etc., manifested by them, which is a particular mental state of the audience, is rasa like love, etc. This is the direction.
The particulars should be known from works that illuminate the tradition.

analyzed: iha an upayogāt na prapañcyate  bhāva svarūpam āha bhāvaḥ vibhāva ityādi
translated: Since they are not useful here, they are not elaborated.

analyzed: vibhāva anubhāvābhyām iti
translated: The nature of the emotion is stated with The emotion is manifested by the excitant, etc.🔽By the excitant and the ensuant.

analyzed: vyabhicāri vyañjane vyabhicāri antara abhāvaḥ vyañjitaḥ
translated: In the manifestation of the variant, the absence of another variant is manifested.

original: vibhāvānubhāvābhyāṃ vyañjito vyabhicāri vākyārthībhāvadaśāyāṃ bhāva ucyate /
analyzed: vibhāva anubhāvābhyām vyañjitaḥ vyabhicāri vākya arthībhāva daśāyām bhāvaḥ ucyate
translated: When it is manifested by the vibhāvas and anubhāvas, and is in the state of being manifested by the transitory emotions, it is called bhāva.

analyzed: saḥ u pi trayastriṃśat bhedaḥ
translated: That also is of thirty-three kinds.

analyzed: nirveda glāni ādi rūpa tayā
translated: In the form of dejection, languor, etc.

original: tathā kāntāvyatirikte devatādiviṣaye vyañjito ratyādirapi bhāvaḥ /

translated: Similarly, the bhāva of love, etc., manifested in the object of worship, etc., which is different from the beloved, is also bhāva.

analyzed: tasmāt vūyabhicāri sthāyī ātmaka tayā bhāvaḥ dvijātikaḥ vagantavyaḥ
translated: Therefore, bhāva should be understood as twofold, consisting of transitory and permanent emotions.

analyzed: yat āha ratiḥ deva ādi viṣayā vyabhicārī tathā añjitaḥ
translated: As it is said: Love towards deities, etc., is manifested as a transitory emotion.

analyzed: bhāvaḥ proktaḥ  ābhāsayoḥ svarūpam āha tad ābhāsaḥ rasa ityādi
translated: Bhāva is said to be thus.🔽He states the nature of the two manifestations, beginning with That manifestation is rasa, etc.

analyzed: tad śabdena rasa bhāva pratyavamarśaḥ
translated: The word that refers to the reflection of rasa and bhāva.

analyzed: ābhāsībhāvaḥ tu aviṣaya pravṛtti ānaucityāt  bhāva praśama svarūpam āha tad praśamaḥ ukta ityādi
translated: But the manifested bhāva is not the object of engagement due to impropriety.🔽He states the nature of the cessation of bhāva, beginning with The cessation of that is said, etc.

analyzed: ukta bhāva prakārāṇām nivṛttau prayāsyat avasthā bhāva praśamaḥ ucyate
translated: The state of being about to depart upon the cessation of the types of bhāva that have been described is called the cessation of bhāva.

original: nanu rase 'pi praśamaḥ kiṃ nocyate ityata āhatatrāpītyādi /
analyzed: nanu rase pi praśamaḥ kim nā ucyate iti atas āha tatra api ityādi
translated: But is cessation not also mentioned in rasa? To this he says There also, etc.

original: rasasya hi akhaṇḍanirantarāyapratīti carvaṇīyasya paramaviśrāntirūpatvāt madhye prayāsya davasthā durlakṣyeti rasavyatiriktapariśiṣṭabhedaviṣayo 🔽'yaṃ praśamo draṣṭavyaḥ /
analyzed: rasasya hi carvaṇīyasya parama viśrānti rūpa tvāt madhye durlakṣyā iti rasa vyatirikta pariśiṣṭa bheda viṣayaḥ  yam praśamaḥ draṣṭavyaḥ
translated: For rasa, which is to be relished as unbroken and uninterrupted, is of the nature of the highest repose. The state of being about to pass away in the middle is difficult to discern, so this pacification should be seen as being about the remaining categories other than rasa.

analyzed: eṣām ca rasa bhāva ādīnām upanibandhe paripāṭyāḥ rasavat ādayaḥ laṅkārāḥ
translated: And in the composition of these rasas, bhāvas, etc., there are the figures of speech beginning with rasavat.

analyzed: catvāri api lakṣya padāni nirvakti rasaḥ vidyate ityādinā
translated: All four terms to be defined are present in the statement rasa exists, etc.

original: yatra hi vyañjanopaskṛte 'rbhidhādivyāpārātmani nibandhe raso 'sti tadrasavat /
analyzed: yatra hi vyañjana upaskṛteḥ ṛbhidhā ādi vyāpāra ātmani nibandhe rasaḥ sti tat rasavat
translated: For where there is rasa in a composition embellished by suggestion and consisting of the operation of denotation, etc., that is rasavat.

analyzed: priyatara nibandhanam eva preyaḥ jñeyam
translated: The Preyas should be known as that which consists of the most beloved composition.

analyzed: ūrjaḥ balam tat yogi nibandhanam eva ūrjasvi
translated: The Urjasvi consists of that composition which is endowed with strength.

original: nanu nibandhane balaṃ nāma kimityata āhaanaucityeti /🔽rasasyānaucityena pravṛttatvāt daurbalyam /

translated: But what is strength in a composition? To this he says inappropriateness, etc.🔽Because rasa occurs inappropriately, there is weakness.

analyzed: nibandhane tu tad upakṛte bala yogaḥ
translated: But in a composition, when that is helped, there is the possession of strength.

analyzed: samāhitaḥ parihāraḥ
translated: The reply is combined.

original: kasya / prakṛtatvāduktasya bhāvabhedasya yasya praśama ityapi paryāyaḥ /
analyzed: kasya prakṛta tvāt uktasya bhāva bhedasya yasya praśamaḥ iti api paryāyaḥ
translated: Of what? Of the mentioned category of bhāvas, which is the subject, and for whom there is pacification, which is also a synonym.

original: nanu rasavadādinā dvitāyodāttasya ca kā kakṣyetyata āhatatra yasminnityādi /
analyzed: nanu rasavat ādinā dvitāya udāttasya ca kā kakṣyā iti atas āha tatra yasmin ityādi

original: yatra hi bhāmahādidarśane vākyārthībhāvāt pradhānabhūtā eva rasādayo rasavadādyalaṅkārāḥ tatra aṅgabhūtarasādiviṣaya upapadyate /

translated: Where, in the view of Bhāmaha and others, Rasa, etc., are the principal factors, being the meaning of the sentence, there the application of the secondary sentiments, etc., is proper.

analyzed: kalpaḥ dvitīyaḥ udātta alaṅkāraḥ
translated: The second kind is the figure Utkarṣa.

original: yasmiṃmastu rasavadādiralaṅkāro aṅgabhūtarasādiviṣaya eva aṅginastu rasāderalaṅkāryabhāvāpannasya
analyzed: rasavat ādiḥ alaṅkāraḥ aṅga bhūta rasa ādi viṣayaḥ eva aṅginaḥ tu rasa ādeḥ alaṅkārya bhāva āpannasya
translated: Where there is the figure Rasa, etc., having the secondary sentiments, etc., as its object, the principal Rasa, etc., which have become the object of embellishment,

analyzed: rasa bhāva ādi dhvani rūpa tayā vyātpa tvāt tatra dhava nidarśane dvitīyasya aṅga bhūta mahāpuruṣa carita lakṣaṇasya udātta alaṅkārasya
translated: are pervaded by the form of dhvani, which is Rasa, Bhāva, etc. There, in the view of those who hold that Rasa, etc., are the meaning of the sentence, the second kind, which is characterized by the conduct of the great man who is a secondary element,

analyzed: viṣayaḥ na avaśiṣyate
translated: of the figure Utkarṣa, does not remain as the object.

analyzed: kutas iti atas āha tad viṣayasya iti
translated: Why is it so? To this he says: “The object of that, etc.”

original: iyamiha prakriyā /🔽yatra rasādayo vākyārthī🔽bhūtāḥ tatra rasavadādayo 'laṅkārā ityalaṅkāramātrarasikānāṃ bhāmahādīnāṃ darśane /
analyzed: iyam iha prakriyā  yatra rasa ādayaḥ vākya arthī  bhūtāḥ tatra rasavat ādayaḥ laṅkārāḥ iti alaṅkāra mātra rasikānām bhāmaha ādīnām darśane
translated: This is the procedure here.🔽Where Rasa, etc., are the meaning of the sentence, there the figures Rasa, etc., are in the view of Bhāmaha and others, who delight only in figures of speech.

analyzed: yadā tu a vākya arthībhāvāt aṅga bhūtaḥ rasa ādiḥ
translated: But when the secondary sentiment, etc., are not the meaning of the sentence,

analyzed: tadā aṅga bhūta mahāpuruṣa carita lakṣaṇaḥ dvitīyaḥ udāttaḥ upapadyate nāma
translated: Then, the second type of the sublime, which is characterized by the conduct of the great hero as a subordinate element, arises.

original: dhvanidarśane tu kāvyātmano rasādeḥ prādhānyadaśāyāṃ alaṅkāryatvādalaṅkārabhāvānupapattau aṅgabhūtā rasādayo rasavadādyalaṅkārāḥ /
analyzed: dhvani darśane tu kāvya ātmanaḥ rasa ādeḥ prādhānya daśāyām alaṅkārya tvāt alaṅkāra bhāva anupapattau aṅga bhūtāḥ rasa ādayaḥ rasavat ādi alaṅkārāḥ
translated: But in the theory of sound and vision, when rasa etc., which is the soul of poetry, is in the state of being primary, it cannot be in the state of being an ornament because of the fact of being what is to be ornamented. Therefore, rasa etc., which are subordinate, are the ornaments rasa-vAda etc.

original: tathā ca sati rasabhāvādināyakamahāpuruṣacaritāvirbhāvo 'pi rasabhāvādyaṅgabhāvānatirekī vyaṅgyavyañjakamanbandhāt /
analyzed: tathā ca sati rasa bhāva ādi nāyaka mahāpuruṣa carita āvirbhāvaḥ pi rasa bhāva ādi aṅga bhāva an atirekī vyaṅgya vyañjaka manbandhāt
translated: And when that is so, even the manifestation of the conduct of the great hero, which is characterized by rasa, bhAva etc., is not different from the state of being a subordinate element of rasa, bhAva etc., because of the relation of the manifested and the manifester.

analyzed: vyañjakam hi mahāpuruṣa caritam  vyaṅgyam rasa bhāva ādi
translated: For the conduct of the great hero is the manifester.🔽Rasa, bhAva etc. are the manifested.

analyzed: vyaṅgya bhāva avinābhūta aṅgabhāvam rasa vat alaṅkārasya eva viṣayaḥ
translated: The object of the ornament rasa-vAda etc. is the state of being a subordinate element which is inseparable from the state of being the manifested.

analyzed: vyañjaka mātra viśrāntānām an avagāḍha dhiyām dvitīya udātta bhramaḥ iti
translated: For those whose intellects are not deeply immersed, who rest content with mere manifestation, there is the delusion of a second type of the sublime.

original: kiṃ hāsyenetisvapnadṛṣṭa nāyakaṃ svarūpasandarśananihnavaparihāsapravṛttaṃ manyamānasya ripustrījanasyoktivarṇanam /
analyzed: kim hāsyena iti svapna dṛṣṭa nāyakam sva rūpa sandarśana nihnava parihāsa pravṛttam manyamānasya ripu strī janasya ukti varṇanam
translated: The description of the words spoken by the women of the enemy, who think that the hero, seen in a dream, is engaged in jesting about concealing his true form.

original: kiṃ hāsyena cirātprātpraḥsan punarme darśanaṃ na prayāsyasi /
analyzed: kim hāsyena cirāt prāt praḥ san punar me darśanam na prayāsyasi
translated: What is the use of laughter? For a long time, you have been pleased, but will not come to see me again.

original: niṣkaruṇatā taveyaṃ prātpisamakālameva pravāsarucitā ityudīrayannevatamadṛṣṭvā kenāsi dūrīkṛtaḥiti vadan vyāsaktakaṇṭhagraho buddhvā riktabāhulayacastāraṃ
analyzed: niṣkaruṇa tā tava iyam pravāsa rucitā iti udīrayan eva tam a dṛṣṭvā kena asi dūrīkṛtaḥ iti vadan vyāsakta kaṇṭha grahaḥ buddhvā
translated: Saying, This your cruelty is the cause of your desire for exile at the very time of your attainment, and not seeing him, saying, By whom are you separated? with his throat choked with tears, he weeps.

analyzed: roditi iti  atra aṅga aṅginau dvau api rasau aṅgī rasaḥ
translated: Thus.

analyzed: rasavān mata antare
translated: Here, both the rasa and the rasavān are subordinate to the rasa, which is the principal element.🔽In another view, the rasavān is considered subordinate.

analyzed: sva mate tu aṅga bhūtaḥ rasavān
translated: But in our view, the rasavān is subordinate.

analyzed: atas udāharaṇam etat mata dvaya arham  tat etat abhisandhāya āha etad mata dvaye pi iti
translated: Therefore, this example is suitable for both views.🔽With this in mind, he says, In both these views...

analyzed: tat etat vibhajya darśayitum āha atra vākya arthībhūtaḥ iti
translated: To explain this, he says, Here, the rasavān is subordinate to the rasa, which is the principal element...

analyzed: vākya arthībhāvāt karuṇe rasavān
translated: Because it becomes the meaning of the sentence, the rasavān is subordinate to the rasa.

analyzed: mata antare iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is, in another view.

analyzed: aṅga bhāvāt vipralaṃbha śṛṅgāraḥ rasavān
translated: Because it is subordinate, the vipralambhaśṛṅgāra is rasavān.

analyzed: asmad mataḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is, in our view.

original: evaṃvidhe hi viṣaye vākyārthībhāvāt aṅginaṃ rasaṃ rasavantamanye pratipedire /
analyzed: evaṃvidhe hi viṣaye vākya arthībhāvāt aṅginam rasam rasavantam anye pratipedire
translated: For in such a case, others accept the rasavān as the principal rasa, which becomes the meaning of the sentence.

analyzed: aṅgi bhūtam tu dvitatīya udāttam
translated: But the second-best is subordinate.

original: dhvanidarśanavidastu aṅgino alaṅkāryatāṃ aṅgibhūtasya rasavadādirūpatāṃ dvitīyodāttāsaṃbhavaṃ ca siddhāntitavantaḥ /
analyzed: dhvani darśana vidaḥ tu aṅginaḥ alaṅkārya tām aṅgi bhūtasya rasavat ādi rūpa tām dvitīya udātta asaṃbhavam ca siddhāntitavantaḥ
translated: But those who know sound and vision have established the view that the subordinate is to be embellished, and that the form of rasa, etc., which is subordinate, is not possible as the second principal element.

original: iyaṃ ca prakriyā rasāntareṣvapi jñeyetyāhaevaṃ rasāntareṣviti /
analyzed: iyam ca prakriyā rasa antareṣu api jñeyā iti āha evam rasa antareṣu iti
translated: And this procedure should be known to apply to other rasas as well, he says: Thus to other rasas, etc.

analyzed: udāhāryam udāhartum arham śakyam
translated: To be cited means to be able to cite.

analyzed: prāt pa kāla tā vā udāharaṇasya
translated: The time for citing has arrived.

analyzed: arhe śakye prāt pa kāla tāyām ca kṛtyaḥ
translated: The suffix kṛtya is used for what is worthy, possible, and has arrived.

analyzed: ittham rasavat alaṅkāre mata dvayam kakṣyā nibhāgena udāhṛtam
translated: Thus, the two views regarding the figure of speech rasa have been cited by dividing them into sections.

original: preyo 'laṅkārādau tu viśeṣāṃśastu jñāta iti sādhāraṇyenodāhīrṣurāhapreyo 'laṅkārādāviti /
analyzed: preyaḥ laṅkāra ādau tu viśeṣa aṃśaḥ tu jñātaḥ iti sādhāraṇyena udāhīrṣuḥ āha preyaḥ laṅkāra ādau iti
translated: But in the case of the figure of speech preyaḥ, etc., the special part is known, so he wishes to cite it in a general way, saying in the case of the figure of speech preyaḥ, etc.

analyzed: gāḍha āliṅganā iti
translated: In the tight embrace, etc.

analyzed: mānada māna khaṇḍana mām eti ardha uktyā bhāva avasāna harṣaḥ pratyāyyate
translated: By the half-statement O honored one, O breaker of pride, O my love, the joy of the end of emotion is conveyed.

analyzed: lakṣyayā udajanāya āha atra niyikāyāḥ iti
translated: To illustrate, he says here the young woman's, etc.

original: harṣākhyo vyabhicāribhāvaḥ sambhogaśṛṅgāraṃprati guṇātvāt preyo 'laṅkāra iti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: harṣa ākhyaḥ vyabhicāri bhāvaḥ sambhoga śṛṅgāram prati preyaḥ laṅkāraḥ iti śeṣaḥ
